text.0: With the same humor and humanity he exuded in An Inconvenient Truth, Al Gore spells out 15 ways that individuals can address climate change immediately, from buying a hybrid to inventing a new, hotter "brand name" for global warming. text.160: "Can we create new life out of our digital universe?" Craig Venter asks. His answer is "yes" -- and pretty soon. text.167: People want to be religious, says scholar Karen Armstrong; we should help make religion a force for harmony. text.243: In this engrossing EG talk, architect Liz Diller shares her firm DS+R's more unusual work, including the Blur Building, whose walls are made of fog, and the revamped Alice Tully Hall, which is wrapped in glowing wooden skin. The Creative Spark,Architectural Inspiration,Art Unusual,architecture,art,arts,cities,design,theater  The Blur Building and other tech-empowered architecture
text.244: Photojournalist James Nachtwey sees his TED Prize wish come true, as we share his powerful photographs of XDR-TB, a drug-resistant strain of tuberculosis that's touching off a global medical crisis. Presentation Innovation,TED Prize Winners,Master Storytellers,TED Prize,arts,communication,design,media,photography,technology  Moving photos of extreme drug-resistant TB
text.245: Outside.in's Steven Johnson says the Web is like a city: built by many people, completely controlled by no one, intricately interconnected and yet functioning as many independent parts. While disaster strikes in one place, elsewhere, life goes on.  The Power of Cities,Unconventional Explanations,TED Conference,cities,communication,community,design,global issues,politics,web  The Web as a city
text.246: Historian Doris Kearns Goodwin talks about what we can learn from American presidents, including Abraham Lincoln and Lyndon Johnson. Then she shares a moving memory of her own father, and of their shared love of baseball. How the Mind Works,Master Storytellers,Technology, History and Destiny,TED Conference,entertainment,history,politics,sports,storytelling  Lessons from past presidents
text.247: Human beatbox James "AudioPoet" Burchfield performs an intricate three-minute breakdown -- sexy, propulsive hip-hop rhythms and turntable textures -- all using only his voice. The Creative Spark,Spectacular Performance,Art Unusual,Live Music,TED Conference,entertainment,humor,illusion,live music,music,performance  Playing invisible turntables
text.248: Why do societies fail? With lessons from the Norse of Iron Age Greenland, deforested Easter Island and present-day Montana, Jared Diamond talks about the signs that collapse is near, and how -- if we see it in time -- we can prevent it. A Greener Future?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Technology, History and Destiny,Unconventional Explanations,TED Conference,culture,environment,global issues,history,social change,society,technology  Why do societies collapse?
text.249: Physicist and surfer Garrett Lisi presents a controversial new model of the universe that -- just maybe -- answers all the big questions. If nothing else, it's the most beautiful 8-dimensional model of elementary particles and forces you've ever seen. To Boldly Go ...,Unconventional Explanations,TED Conference,physics,science,technology  An 8-dimensional model of the universe
text.250: Humorist John Hodgman rambles through a new story about aliens, physics, time, space and the way all of these somehow contribute to a sweet, perfect memory of falling in love.  The Creative Spark,Peering into Space,Unconventional Explanations,Whipsmart Comedy,TED Conference,entertainment,extraterrestrial life,humor,love,physics,science,time  Aliens, love -- where are they?
text.251: Dean Ornish talks about simple, low-tech and low-cost ways to take advantage of the body's natural desire to heal itself. Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,Medicine Without Borders,TED Conference,health,health care,medicine,science  Healing through diet
text.252: In 1998, aircraft designer Paul MacCready looks at a planet on which humans have utterly dominated nature, and talks about what we all can do to preserve nature's balance. His contribution: solar planes, superefficient gliders and the electric car. A Greener Future?,Design That Matters,War and Peace,TED Conference,demo,design,drones,flight,green,solar,technology,transportation  Nature vs. humans
text.253: In this moving talk, documentary photographer Kristen Ashburn shares unforgettable images of the human impact of AIDS in Africa. To Boldly Go ...,Africa: The Next Chapter,Medicine Without Borders,Media With Meaning,AIDS,Africa,TED Conference,activism,disease,global issues,health,media,photography,science  The face of AIDS in Africa
text.254: Rives tells a typographical fairy tale that's short and bittersweet ;) Master Storytellers,TED in 3 Minutes,Words About Words,TED Conference,design,entertainment,humor,love,media,poetry,storytelling  A story of mixed emoticons
text.255: The Inventables guys, Zach Kaplan and Keith Schacht, demo some amazing new materials and how we might use them. Look for squishy magnets, odor-detecting ink, "dry" liquid and a very surprising 10-foot pole.  The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,TED Conference,business,creativity,design,industrial design,invention,materials,science,smell,technology,toy  Toys and materials from the future
text.256: Filmmaker Newton Aduaka shows clips from his powerful, lyrical feature film "Ezra," about a child soldier in Sierra Leone. The Creative Spark,Master Storytellers,Africa: The Next Chapter,War and Peace,Media With Meaning,Africa,arts,creativity,culture,entertainment,film,global issues,war  The story of Ezra
text.257: Graham Hawkes takes us aboard his graceful, winged submarines to the depths of planet Ocean (a.k.a. "Earth"). It's a deep blue world we landlubbers rarely see in 3D. The Creative Spark,Animals That Amaze,What's Next in Tech,Inspired by Nature,Tales of Invention,Ocean Wonders,TED Conference,business,design,exploration,invention,oceans,technology  A flight through the ocean
text.258: James Surowiecki pinpoints the moment when social media became an equal player in the world of news-gathering: the 2005 tsunami, when YouTube video, blogs, IMs and txts carried the news -- and preserved moving personal stories from the tragedy. The Rise of Collaboration,Media With Meaning,TED Conference,culture,entertainment,media,social change,social media,technology  The power and the danger of online crowds
text.259: For almost three decades, John Francis has been a planetwalker, traveling the globe by foot and sail with a message of environmental respect and responsibility (for 17 of those years without speaking). A funny, thoughtful talk with occasional banjo. A Greener Future?,To Boldly Go ...,Unconventional Explanations,TED Conference,activism,environment,global issues  Walk the earth ... my 17-year vow of silence
text.260: At the 2008 Serious Play conference, designer Tim Brown talks about the powerful relationship between creative thinking and play -- with many examples you can try at home (and one that maybe you shouldn't). The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,Design That Matters,Unconventional Explanations,art,creativity,design,education,play,toy  Tales of creativity and play
text.261: What's the science behind a sublime perfume? With charm and precision, biophysicist Luca Turin explains the molecular makeup -- and the art -- of a scent. Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,Senses,TED Conference,beauty,happiness,materials,science,smell,technology  The science of scent
text.262: Physicist Lee Smolin talks about how the scientific community works: as he puts it, "we fight and argue as hard as we can," but everyone accepts that the next generation of scientists will decide who's right. And, he says, that's how democracy works, too. Technology, History and Destiny,How We Learn,String theory,TED Conference,community,global issues,physics,politics,science,social change  Science and democracy
text.263: Would you negotiate with someone you knew to be evil, to save lives? Samantha Power tells a story of a complicated hero, Sergio Vieira de Mello. This UN diplomat walked a thin moral line, negotiating with the world's worst dictators to help their people survive crisis. It's a compelling story told with a fiery passion. Rethinking Poverty,Master Storytellers,War and Peace,Media With Meaning,TED Conference,communication,global issues,morality,politics,terrorism,war  A complicated hero in the war on dictatorship
text.264: Fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi spins through a dizzying array of inspirations -- from '50s pinups to a fleeting glimpse of a woman on the street who makes him shout "Stop the cab!" Inside this rambling talk are real clues to living a happy, creative life. The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,Unconventional Explanations,business,creativity,design,entertainment,fashion,humor,media  Fashion and creativity
text.265: Ursus Wehrli shares his vision for a cleaner, more organized, tidier form of art -- by deconstructing the paintings of modern masters into their component pieces, sorted by color and size. Art Unusual,Unconventional Explanations,Whipsmart Comedy,TED Conference,art,arts,design,entertainment,humor,performance,simplicity  Tidying up art
text.266: Stewart Brand works on the Clock of the Long Now, a timepiece that counts down the next 10,000 years. It's a beautiful project that asks us to think about the far, far future. Here, he discusses a tricky side problem with the Clock: Where can we put it?  Tales of Invention,Technology, History and Destiny,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,TED Conference,architecture,art,design,future,technology  The Long Now
text.267: At Serious Play 2008, astrophysicist George Smoot shows stunning new images from deep-space surveys, and prods us to ponder how the cosmos -- with its giant webs of dark matter and mysterious gaping voids -- got built this way. Inspired by Nature,To Boldly Go ...,Is There a God?,Peering into Space,astronomy,culture,dark matter,design,physics,science,space,technology,time  The design of the universe
text.268: Technologist and futurist Bill Joy talks about several big worries for humanity -- and several big hopes in the fields of health, education and future tech.  What's Next in Tech,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Technology, History and Destiny,TED Conference,business,future,health,science,technology  What I'm worried about, what I'm excited about
text.269: Biochemist Gregory Petsko makes a convincing argument that, in the next 50 years, we'll see an epidemic of neurological diseases, such as Alzheimer's, as the world population ages. His solution: more research into the brain and its functions.  How the Mind Works,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,Medicine Without Borders,TED Conference,aging,brain,business,health,public health,science,social change,technology  The coming neurological epidemic
text.270: Science writer Richard Preston talks about some of the most enormous living beings on the planet, the giant trees of the US Pacific Northwest. Growing from a tiny seed, they support vast ecosystems -- and are still, largely, a mystery.  Evolution's Genius,Inspired by Nature,To Boldly Go ...,Master Storytellers,TED Conference,arts,complexity,exploration,nature,science,trees,writing  The mysterious lives of giant trees
text.271: Why build a virtual world? Philip Rosedale talks about the virtual society he founded, Second Life, and its underpinnings in human creativity. It's a place so different that anything could happen. The Creative Spark,The Power of Cities,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,Not Business as Usual,Technology, History and Destiny,What Makes Us Happy?,Media With Meaning,cities,communication,community,computers,entertainment,entrepreneur,life,technology  Life in Second Life
text.272: General Motors veep Larry Burns previews cool next-gen car design: sleek, customizable (and computer-enhanced) vehicles that run clean on hydrogen -- and pump energy back into the electrical grid when they're idle. What's Next in Tech,A Greener Future?,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,TED Conference,alternative energy,cars,design,energy,future,green,technology  The future of cars
text.273: Inventor Nick Sears demos the first generation of the Orb, a rotating persistence-of-vision display that creates glowing 3D images. A short, cool tale of invention.  The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,TED in 3 Minutes,TED Conference,demo,design,entertainment,invention,technology  Demo
text.274: Folk musician and storyteller David Holt plays the banjo and shares photographs and old wisdom from the Appalachian Mountains. He also demonstrates some unusual instruments like the mouth bow -- and a surprising electric drum kit he calls "thunderwear." The Creative Spark,Spectacular Performance,Master Storytellers,Live Music,TED Conference,arts,culture,entertainment,invention,music,storytelling  The joyful tradition of mountain music
text.275: The ceramics designer Eva Zeisel looks back on a 75-year career. What keeps her work as fresh today (her latest line debuted in 2008) as in 1926? Her sense of play and beauty, and her drive for adventure. Listen for stories from a rich, colorful life. The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,Master Storytellers,What Makes Us Happy?,TED Conference,arts,creativity,design,exploration,play,politics  The playful search for beauty
text.276: Bees are dying in droves. Why? Leading apiarist Dennis vanEngelsdorp looks at the gentle, misunderstood creature's important place in nature and the mystery behind its alarming disappearance. Animals That Amaze,Evolution's Genius,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,animals,bees,disease,food,insects,life,nature  A plea for bees
text.277: Can happiness be bought? To find out, author Benjamin Wallace sampled the world's most expensive products, including a bottle of 1947 Chateau Cheval Blanc, 8 ounces of Kobe beef and the fabled (notorious) Kopi Luwak coffee. His critique may surprise you. How the Mind Works,Master Storytellers,Unconventional Explanations,Food Matters,book,business,culture,entertainment,food,happiness,writing  The price of happiness
text.278: Dan Gilbert presents research and data from his exploration of happiness -- sharing some surprising tests and experiments that you can also try on yourself. Watch through to the end for a sparkling Q&A with some familiar TED faces. How the Mind Works,Unconventional Explanations,What Makes Us Happy?,brain,choice,culture,entertainment,goal-setting,happiness,psychology,self,society  Why we make bad decisions
text.279: Mathematician Steven Strogatz shows how flocks of creatures (like birds, fireflies and fish) manage to synchronize and act as a unit -- when no one's giving orders. The powerful tendency extends into the realm of objects, too. Presentation Innovation,Inspired by Nature,Unconventional Explanations,Numbers at Play,TED Conference,biology,biomechanics,math,science,society,technology  The science of sync
text.280: TED follows Nicholas Negroponte to Colombia as he delivers laptops inside territory once controlled by guerrillas. His partner? Colombia's Defense Department, who see One Laptop per Child as an investment in the region. (And you too can get involved.) What's Next in Tech,Presentation Innovation,Rethinking Poverty,One Laptop Per Child,children,computers,design,education,global issues,philanthropy,politics,technology  Taking OLPC to Colombia
text.281: Biochemist Kary Mullis talks about the basis of modern science: the experiment. Sharing tales from the 17th century and from his own backyard-rocketry days, Mullis celebrates the curiosity, inspiration and rigor of good science in all its forms. How the Mind Works,Inspired by Nature,Technology, History and Destiny,How We Learn,DNA,TED Conference,biology,curiosity,history,microbiology,science,technology  Play! Experiment! Discover!
text.282: Designer John Maeda talks about his path from a Seattle tofu factory to the Rhode Island School of Design, where he became president in 2008. Maeda, a tireless experimenter and a witty observer, explores the crucial moment when design met computers. The Creative Spark,Art Unusual,arts,computers,curiosity,design,education,technology  My journey in design
text.283: Strange landscapes, scorching heat and (sometimes) mad crocodiles await scientists seeking clues to evolution's genius. Paleontologist Paul Sereno talks about his surprising encounters with prehistory -- and a new way to help students join the adventure. Animals That Amaze,Evolution's Genius,Inspired by Nature,To Boldly Go ...,How We Learn,Africa,animals,biology,dinosaurs,education,evolution,exploration,history,life,paleontology  Digging up dinosaurs
text.284: Paul Moller talks about the future of personal air travel -- the marriage of autos and flight that will give us true freedom to travel off-road. He shows two things he's working on: the Moller Skycar (a jet + car) and a passenger-friendly hovering disc. What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,To Boldly Go ...,Technology, History and Destiny,TED Conference,design,engineering,invention,technology,transportation  My dream of a flying car
text.285: Greg Lynn talks about the mathematical roots of architecture -- and how calculus and digital tools allow modern designers to move beyond the traditional building forms. A glorious church in Queens (and a titanium tea set) illustrate his theory. The Creative Spark,Numbers at Play,TED Conference,design  Organic algorithms in architecture
text.286: In this unmissable look at the magic of comics, Scott McCloud bends the presentation format into a cartoon-like experience, where colorful diversions whiz through childhood fascinations and imagined futures that our eyes can hear and touch. The Creative Spark,How the Mind Works,Presentation Innovation,Tales of Invention,Master Storytellers,Technology, History and Destiny,Unconventional Explanations,What Makes Us Happy?,Whipsmart Comedy,Words About Words,TED Conference,art,arts,book,children,computers,creativity,design,entertainment,future,history  The visual magic of comics
text.287: Great design is a never-ending journey of discovery -- for which it helps to pack a healthy sense of humor. Sociologist and surfer-turned-designer David Carson walks through a gorgeous (and often quite funny) slide deck of his work and found images. Art Unusual,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,What Makes Us Happy?,Media With Meaning,TED Conference,design,exploration,humor,photography,typography  Design and discovery
text.288: What is genomics? How will it affect our lives? In this intriguing primer on the genomics revolution, entrepreneur Barry Schuler says we can at least expect healthier, tastier food. He suggests we start with the pinot noir grape, to build better wines. Evolution's Genius,What's Next in Tech,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,biology,entrepreneur,food,genetics,science,technology  Genomics 101
text.289: We all want to make the world better -- but how? Jamais Cascio looks at some specific tools and techniques that can make a difference. It's a fascinating talk that might just inspire you to act. What's Next in Tech,A Greener Future?,Tales of Invention,TED Conference,culture,future,global issues,social change,technology  Tools for a better world
text.290: Asteroid strikes get all the coverage, but "Medea Hypothesis" author Peter Ward argues that most of Earth's mass extinctions were caused by lowly bacteria. The culprit, a poison called hydrogen sulfide, may have an interesting application in medicine. Animals That Amaze,A Greener Future?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Technology, History and Destiny,Medicine Without Borders,dinosaurs,disease,environment,history,life,science,space  A theory of Earth's mass extinctions
text.291: Surgeon and writer Sherwin Nuland meditates on the idea of hope -- the desire to become our better selves and make a better world. It's a thoughtful 12 minutes that will help you focus on the road ahead. Master Storytellers,Words About Words,TED Conference,philanthropy,philosophy,writing  The extraordinary power of ordinary people
text.292: Woody Norris shows off two of his inventions that use sound in new ways, including the Long Range Acoustic Device, or LRAD. He talks about his untraditional approach to inventing and education, because, as he puts it: "Almost nothing has been invented yet." So -- what's next? The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,TED Conference,business,creativity,design,invention,technology  Hypersonic sound and other inventions
text.293: In this TED archive video from 1998, paralympic sprinter Aimee Mullins talks about her record-setting career as a runner, and about the amazing carbon-fiber prosthetic legs (then a prototype) that helped her cross the finish line. What's Next in Tech,Master Storytellers,Medicine Without Borders,Women Reshaping the World,TED Conference,beauty,body language,design,prosthetics,sports,technology  Changing my legs - and my mindset
text.294: Biochemist Joe DeRisi talks about amazing new ways to diagnose viruses (and treat the illnesses they cause) using DNA. His work may help us understand malaria, SARS, avian flu -- and the 60 percent of everyday viral infections that go undiagnosed. Tales of Invention,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Medicine Without Borders,TED Conference,global issues,illness,medicine,science,technology,virus  Solving medical mysteries
text.295: Natalie MacMaster and her musical partner Donnell Leahy play several tunes from the Cape Breton tradition -- a sprightly, soulful style of folk fiddling. It's an inspired collaboration that will have you clapping (and maybe dancing) along. The Creative Spark,Live Music,TED Conference,arts,collaboration,culture,entertainment,music,piano,violin  Fiddling in reel time
text.296: Bill Gross, the founder of Idealab, talks about his life as an inventor, starting with his high-school company selling solar energy plans and kits. Learn here about a groundbreaking system for solar cells -- and some questions we haven't yet solved. The Creative Spark,TED Conference,energy,invention,solar energy,technology  A solar energy system that tracks the sun
text.297: Bill Gates hopes to solve some of the world's biggest problems using a new kind of philanthropy. In a passionate and, yes, funny 18 minutes, he asks us to consider two big questions and how we might answer them. (And see the Q&A on the TED Blog.) Tales of Invention,Rethinking Poverty,Not Business as Usual,TED Conference,business,education,health,illness,insects,philanthropy,science,technology  Mosquitos, malaria and education
text.298: Elizabeth Gilbert muses on the impossible things we expect from artists and geniuses -- and shares the radical idea that, instead of the rare person "being" a genius, all of us "have" a genius. It's a funny, personal and surprisingly moving talk. The Creative Spark,Words About Words,Women Reshaping the World,TED Conference,arts,creativity,culture,entertainment,poetry,work,writing  Your elusive creative genius
text.299: From the TED archives: The legendary graphic designer Milton Glaser dives deep into a new painting inspired by Piero della Francesca. From here, he muses on what makes a convincing poster, by breaking down an idea and making it new. The Creative Spark,Design That Matters,Words About Words,TED Conference,art,communication,creativity,culture,design,education  Using design to make ideas new
text.300: MIT grad student David Merrill demos Siftables -- cookie-sized, computerized tiles you can stack and shuffle in your hands. These future-toys can do math, play music, and talk to their friends, too. Is this the next thing in hands-on learning? The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Design That Matters,What Makes Us Happy?,TED Conference,art,business,children,computers,design,education,invention,music,technology,toy  Toy tiles that talk to each other
text.301: Barry Schwartz makes a passionate call for "practical wisdom" as an antidote to a society gone mad with bureaucracy. He argues powerfully that rules often fail us, incentives often backfire, and practical, everyday wisdom will help rebuild our world. How the Mind Works,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,TED Conference,business,culture,global issues,philosophy,politics,self,social change,society  Our loss of wisdom
text.302: Even as mega-banks topple, Juan Enriquez says the big reboot is yet to come. But don't look for it on your ballot -- or in the stock exchange. It'll come from science labs, and it promises keener bodies and minds. Our kids are going to be ... different. What's Next in Tech,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,TED Conference,TEDBooks,biology,business,economics,robots,science,technology  The next species of human
text.303: The Teresa Carreño Youth Orchestra contains the best high school musicians from Venezuela's life-changing music program, El Sistema. Led here by Gustavo Dudamel, they play Shostakovich's Symphony No. 10, 2nd movement, and Arturo Márquez' Danzón No. 2. The Creative Spark,TED Prize Winners,Art Unusual,What Makes Us Happy?,TED Conference,TED Prize,arts,children,conducting,culture,education,entertainment,music  El Sistema's top youth orchestra
text.304: The SETI Institute's Jill Tarter makes her TED Prize wish: to accelerate our search for cosmic company. Using a growing array of radio telescopes, she and her team listen for patterns that may be a sign of intelligence elsewhere in the universe. TED Prize Winners,To Boldly Go ...,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Peering into Space,Technology, History and Destiny,TED Conference,TED Prize,exploration,extraterrestrial life,intelligence,science,space,universe  Join the SETI search
text.305: Ed Ulbrich, the digital-effects guru from Digital Domain, explains the Oscar-winning technology that allowed his team to digitally create the older versions of Brad Pitt's face for "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button." The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Master Storytellers,TED Conference,aging,arts,business,entertainment,film,technology  How Benjamin Button got his face
text.306: Capt. Charles Moore of the Algalita Marine Research Foundation first discovered the Great Pacific Garbage Patch -- an endless floating waste of plastic trash. Now he's drawing attention to the growing, choking problem of plastic debris in our seas. A Greener Future?,To Boldly Go ...,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Ocean Wonders,TED Conference,business,environment,oceans,plastic,science  Seas of plastic
text.307: In this illuminating talk, Richard Pyle shows us thriving life on the cliffs of coral reefs and groundbreaking diving technologies he has pioneered to explore it. He and his team risk everything to reveal the secrets of undiscovered species.  Evolution's Genius,Tales of Invention,To Boldly Go ...,Ocean Wonders,TED Conference,biodiversity,exploration,fear,fish,oceans,science,technology  A dive into the reef's Twilight Zone
text.308: At the 2008 EG Conference, artist Miru Kim talks about her work. Kim explores industrial ruins underneath New York and then photographs herself in them, nude -- to bring these massive, dangerous, hidden spaces into sharp focus. The Creative Spark,To Boldly Go ...,art,arts,beauty,cities,entertainment,exploration,photography  My underground art explorations
text.309: In the year leading up to this talk, the web tool Twitter exploded in size (up 10x during 2008 alone). Co-founder Evan Williams reveals that many of the ideas driving that growth came from unexpected uses invented by the users themselves. What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Not Business as Usual,Words About Words,TED Conference,business,communication,culture,entertainment,social change,social media,technology  The voices of Twitter users
text.310: A TED archive gem. At TED in 1998, Brenda Laurel asks: Why are all the top-selling videogames aimed at little boys? She spent two years researching the world of girls (and shares amazing interviews and photos) to create a game that girls would love. Master Storytellers,Media With Meaning,TED Conference,arts,children,culture,design,entertainment,gaming,technology,women  Games for girls
text.311: By piecing together a complex ecological puzzle, biologist Willie Smits believes he has found a way to re-grow clearcut rainforest in Borneo, saving local orangutans — and creating a thrilling blueprint for restoring fragile ecosystems. NOTE: The core content of this talk has been challenged on a number of grounds. For details, and Willie Smits' response, please see "A challenge to Willie Smits' talk" below. Animals That Amaze,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Rethinking Poverty,TED Conference,animals,biodiversity,biosphere,global issues,green,science,trees  How to restore a rainforest
text.312: A unique ecosystem of plants, birds and monkeys thrives in the treetops of the rainforest. Nalini Nadkarni explores these canopy worlds -- and shares her findings with the world below, through dance, art and bold partnerships. Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Women Reshaping the World,TED Conference,activism,animals,biodiversity,biology,biosphere,children,education,environment,insects,trees  Conserving the canopy
text.313: In this talk from 2003, design critic Don Norman turns his incisive eye toward beauty, fun, pleasure and emotion, as he looks at design that makes people happy. He names the three emotional cues that a well-designed product must hit to succeed. The Creative Spark,Unconventional Explanations,What Makes Us Happy?,TED Conference,creativity,design,happiness  3 ways good design makes you happy
text.314: This demo -- from Pattie Maes' lab at MIT, spearheaded by Pranav Mistry -- was the buzz of TED. It's a wearable device with a projector that paves the way for profound interaction with our environment. Imagine "Minority Report" and then some. What's Next in Tech,TED Conference,demo,design,interface design,technology  Meet the SixthSense interaction
text.315: Athlete, actor and activist Aimee Mullins talks about her prosthetic legs -- she's got a dozen amazing pairs -- and the superpowers they grant her: speed, beauty, an extra 6 inches of height ... Quite simply, she redefines what the body can be. Evolution's Genius,What's Next in Tech,Design That Matters,TED Conference,activism,design,fashion,future,prosthetics,sports,technology  My 12 pairs of legs
text.316: A pioneer in research on play, Dr. Stuart Brown says humor, games, roughhousing, flirtation and fantasy are more than just fun. Plenty of play in childhood makes for happy, smart adults -- and keeping it up can make us smarter at any age. The Creative Spark,How the Mind Works,Tales of Invention,Unconventional Explanations,What Makes Us Happy?,How We Learn,brain,children,education,entertainment,gaming,happiness,health,play,psychology,science  Play is more than just fun
text.317: Why are babies cute? Why is cake sweet? Philosopher Dan Dennett has answers you wouldn't expect, as he shares evolution's counterintuitive reasoning on cute, sweet and sexy things (plus a new theory from Matthew Hurley on why jokes are funny). Evolution's Genius,How the Mind Works,Unconventional Explanations,What Makes Us Happy?,TED Conference,animals,biology,children,comedy,evolution,food,humanity,humor,primates,sex  Cute, sexy, sweet, funny
text.318: Behavioral economist Dan Ariely studies the bugs in our moral code: the hidden reasons we think it's OK to cheat or steal (sometimes). Clever studies help make his point that we're predictably irrational -- and can be influenced in ways we can't grasp. How the Mind Works,Unconventional Explanations,What Makes Us Happy?,TED Conference,brain,culture,economics,evil,motivation,psychology,science,self,society  Our buggy moral code
text.319: Adam Savage talks about his fascination with the dodo bird, and how it led him on a strange and surprising double quest. text.397: The varieties of wheat, corn and rice we grow today may not thrive in a future threatened by climate change. Cary Fowler takes us inside a vast global seed bank, buried within a frozen mountain in Norway, that stores a diverse group of food-crop for whatever tomorrow may bring. Evolution's Genius,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Food Matters,agriculture,biodiversity,biosphere,climate change,disaster relief,environment  One seed at a time, protecting the future of food
text.398: Josh Silver delivers his brilliantly simple solution for correcting vision at the lowest cost possible -- adjustable, liquid-filled lenses. At TEDGlobal 2009, he demos his affordable eyeglasses and reveals his global plan to distribute them to a billion people in need by 2020. The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,Rethinking Poverty,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,development,global issues,health,health care,innovation,invention,product design,sight  Adjustable liquid-filled eyeglasses
text.399: As we reboot the world's economy, Geoff Mulgan poses a question: Instead of sending bailout money to doomed old industries, why not use stimulus funds to bootstrap some new, socially responsible companies -- and make the world a little bit better? Not Business as Usual,culture,design,education,health,social change,technology  Post-crash, investing in a better world
text.400: Evan Grant demonstrates the science and art of cymatics, a process for making soundwaves visible. Useful for analyzing complex sounds (like dolphin calls), it also makes complex and beautiful designs. The Creative Spark,design,math,presentation,science,visualizations  Making sound visible through cymatics
text.401: Photographer James Balog shares new image sequences from the Extreme Ice Survey, a network of time-lapse cameras recording glaciers receding at an alarming rate, some of the most vivid evidence yet of climate change.  A Greener Future?,To Boldly Go ...,Media With Meaning,climate change,global issues,photography,science,technology  Time-lapse proof of extreme ice loss
text.402: Lewis Pugh talks about his record-breaking swim across the North Pole. He braved the icy waters (in a Speedo) to highlight the melting icecap. Watch for astonishing footage -- and some blunt commentary on the realities of supercold-water swims. Inspired by Nature,To Boldly Go ...,adventure,climate change,science,sports  How I swam the North Pole
text.403: Sensing the motives and feelings of others is a natural talent for humans. But how do we do it? Here, Rebecca Saxe shares fascinating lab work that uncovers how the brain thinks about other peoples' thoughts -- and judges their actions. How the Mind Works,Unconventional Explanations,brain,morality,science,technology  How we read each other's minds
text.404: Journalist Misha Glenny spent several years in a courageous investigation of  organized crime networks worldwide, which have grown to an estimated 15% of the global economy. From the Russian mafia, to giant drug cartels, his sources include not just intelligence and law enforcement officials but criminal insiders. Art Unusual,Rethinking Poverty,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,adventure,crime,economics,global issues,writing  How global crime networks work
text.405: Danish architect Bjarke Ingels rockets through photo/video-mingled stories of his eco-flashy designs. His buildings not only look like nature -- they act like nature: blocking the wind, collecting solar energy -- and creating stunning views. The Creative Spark,The Power of Cities,Architectural Inspiration,Design That Matters,architecture,cities,creativity,design,environment,green  3 warp-speed architecture tales
text.406: Nature's mysteries meet tack-sharp wit in this hilarious, 10-minute mix of quips and fun lessons, as comedian, writer and TV man John Lloyd plucks at the substance of several things not seen. Master Storytellers,Unconventional Explanations,Whipsmart Comedy,comedy,philosophy,science  An inventory of the invisible
text.407: Neurologist and author Oliver Sacks brings our attention to Charles Bonnet syndrome -- when visually impaired people experience lucid hallucinations. He describes the experiences of his patients in heartwarming detail and walks us through the biology of this under-reported phenomenon.  The Creative Spark,How the Mind Works,TED Conference,biology,brain,medicine,mental health,mind,neurology,psychology,sight  What hallucination reveals about our minds
text.408: Feeling like the world is becoming less friendly? Social theorist Jonathan Zittrain begs to difffer. The Internet, he suggests, is made up of millions of disinterested acts of kindness, curiosity and trust. The Rise of Collaboration,Media With Meaning,Internet,culture,law,technology,web,wikipedia  The Web as random acts of kindness
text.409: At age 14, in poverty and famine, a Malawian boy built a windmill to power his family's home. Now at 22, William Kamkwamba, who speaks at TED, here, for the second time, shares in his own words the moving tale of invention that changed his life. The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,Africa: The Next Chapter,Talks from TED Fellows,Africa,creativity,energy,invention,poverty  How I harnessed the wind
text.410: Taryn Simon exhibits her startling take on photography -- to reveal worlds and people we would never see otherwise. She shares two projects: one documents otherworldly locations typically kept secret from the public, the other involves haunting portraits of men convicted for crimes they did not commit. The Creative Spark,Art Unusual,Media With Meaning,adventure,art,arts,culture,curiosity,photography  Photographs of secret sites
text.411: The debate over foreign aid often pits those who mistrust "charity" against those who mistrust reliance on the markets. Jacqueline Novogratz proposes a middle way she calls patient capital, with promising examples of entrepreneurial innovation driving social change. Rethinking Poverty,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,Africa,business,development,economics,global issues,innovation,invention,poverty,third world,women  A third way to think about aid
text.412: Many people think the lines on the map no longer matter, but Parag Khanna says they do. Using maps of the past and present, he explains the root causes of border conflicts worldwide and proposes simple yet cunning solutions for each. The Power of Cities,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Technology, History and Destiny,Unconventional Explanations,Asia,economics,global issues,history,map,politics,state-building,war,world cultures  Mapping the future of countries
text.413: Tim Brown says the design profession has a bigger role to play than just creating nifty, fashionable little objects. He calls for a shift to local, collaborative, participatory "design thinking" -- starting with the example of 19th-century design thinker Isambard Kingdom Brunel. The Creative Spark,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,Technology, History and Destiny,art,business,design,green,history,product design  Designers -- think big!
text.414: Weeks from the Charter for Compassion launch, Karen Armstrong looks at religion's role in the 21st century: Will its dogmas divide us? Or will it unite us for common good? She reviews the catalysts that can drive the world's faiths to rediscover the Golden Rule. TED Prize Winners,Is There a God?,Media With Meaning,God,TED Prize,global issues,politics,religion,violence  Let's revive the Golden Rule
text.415: Garik Israelian is a spectroscopist, studying the spectrum emitted by a star to figure out what it's made of and how it might behave. It's a rare and accessible look at this discipline, which may be coming close to finding a planet friendly to life. To Boldly Go ...,Peering into Space,astronomy,chemistry,life,science,technology,universe  How spectroscopy could reveal alien life
text.416: Every seven years, designer Stefan Sagmeister closes his New York studio for a yearlong sabbatical to rejuvenate and refresh their creative outlook. He explains the often overlooked value of time off and shows the innovative projects inspired by his time in Bali. The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,What Makes Us Happy?,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,adventure,art,creativity,design,happiness,innovation,work  The power of time off
text.417: David Logan talks about the five kinds of tribes that humans naturally form -- in schools, workplaces, even the driver's license bureau. By understanding our shared tribal tendencies, we can help lead each other to become better individuals. The Rise of Collaboration,Not Business as Usual,TEDx,business,communication,culture,leadership,society  Tribal leadership
text.418: Our lives, our cultures, are composed of many overlapping stories. Novelist Chimamanda Adichie tells the story of how she found her authentic cultural voice -- and warns that if we hear only a single story about another person or country, we risk a critical misunderstanding. The Creative Spark,Master Storytellers,Words About Words,Women Reshaping the World,Africa,book,culture,identity,storytelling,writing  The danger of a single story
text.419: Beau Lotto's color games puzzle your vision, but they also spotlight what you can't normally see: how your brain works. This fun, first-hand look at your own versatile sense of sight reveals how evolution tints your perception of what's really out there. Evolution's Genius,How the Mind Works,Art Unusual,art,brain,consciousness,mind,psychology,science,visualizations  Optical illusions show how we see
text.420: David Hanson's robot faces look and act like yours: They recognize and respond to emotion, and make expressions of their own. Here, an "emotional" live demo of the Einstein robot offers a peek at a future where robots truly mimic humans. The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,TED Conference,body language,demo,design,engineering,entertainment,robots,technology  Robots that "show emotion"
text.421: Henry Markram says the mysteries of the mind can be solved -- soon. Mental illness, memory, perception: they're made of neurons and electric signals, and he plans to find them with a supercomputer that models all the brain's 100,000,000,000,000 synapses. How the Mind Works,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,brain,computers,consciousness,mind,neurology,philosophy,technology  A brain in a supercomputer
text.422: Computer graphics trailblazer Paul Debevec explains the scene-stealing technology behind Digital Emily, a digitally constructed human face so realistic it stands up to multiple takes. The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,TEDx,art,computers,design,film,technology,visualizations  Animating a photo-real digital face
text.423: An orchestra conductor faces the ultimate leadership challenge: creating perfect harmony without saying a word. In this charming talk, Itay Talgam demonstrates the unique styles of six great 20th-century conductors, illustrating crucial lessons for all leaders.  The Creative Spark,Presentation Innovation,Art Unusual,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,business,conducting,leadership,music,psychology,society  Lead like the great conductors
text.424: Reuse of syringes, all too common in under-funded clinics, kills 1.3 million each year. Marc Koska clues us in to this devastating global problem with facts, photos and hidden-camera footage. He shares his solution: a low-cost syringe that can't be used twice. What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Not Business as Usual,design,development,education,health,medicine,sanitation,science,technology  1.3m reasons to re-invent the syringe
text.425: For tens of thousands of years our ancestors understood the world through myths, and the pace of change was glacial. The rise of scientific understanding transformed the world within a few centuries. Why? Physicist David Deutsch proposes a subtle answer. Peering into Space,Technology, History and Destiny,Unconventional Explanations,ancient world,cosmos,faith,history,philosophy,physics,religion,science,technology  A new way to explain explanation
text.426: Becky Blanton planned to live in her van for a year and see the country, but when depression set in and her freelance job ended, her camping trip turned into homelessness. In this intimate talk, she describes her experience of becoming one of America's working homeless.  The Creative Spark,Rethinking Poverty,Master Storytellers,Unconventional Explanations,What Makes Us Happy?,depression,happiness,life,personal growth,poverty,social change,society,storytelling  The year I was homeless
text.427: The world turns on symmetry -- from the spin of subatomic particles to the dizzying beauty of an arabesque. But there's more to it than meets the eye. Here, Oxford mathematician Marcus du Sautoy offers a glimpse of the invisible numbers that marry all symmetrical objects. Architectural Inspiration,Inspired by Nature,Art Unusual,Numbers at Play,architecture,art,beauty,math,physics,universe  Symmetry, reality's riddle
text.428: While we all agree that compassion is a great idea, Rabbi Tabick acknowledges there are challenges to its execution. She explains how a careful balance of compassion and justice allows us to do good deeds, and keep our sanity.   The Charter for Compassion,charter for compassion,compassion,global issues,religion  The balancing act of compassion
text.429: Swami Dayananda Saraswati unravels the parallel paths of personal development and attaining true compassion. He walks us through each step of self-realization, from helpless infancy to the fearless act of caring for others. The Charter for Compassion,charter for compassion,chautauqua,compassion,global issues,religion,self  The profound journey of compassion
text.430: Join Rev. James Forbes at the dinner table of his Southern childhood, where his mother and father taught him what compassion really means day to day -- sharing with those who need love. The Charter for Compassion,charter for compassion,chautauqua,compassion,faith,global issues,life,religion  Compassion at the dinner table
text.431: Imam Faisal Abdul Rauf combines the teachings of the Qur’an, the stories of Rumi, and the examples of Muhammad and Jesus, to demonstrate that only one obstacle stands between each of us and absolute compassion -- ourselves.   The Charter for Compassion,charter for compassion,compassion,global issues,religion  Lose your ego, find your compassion
text.432: It’s hard to always show compassion -- even to the people we love, but Robert Thurman asks that we develop compassion for our enemies. He prescribes a seven-step meditation exercise to extend compassion beyond our inner circle. The Charter for Compassion,charter for compassion,chautauqua,compassion,global issues,love,religion,self  Expanding your circle of compassion
text.433: Robert Wright uses evolutionary biology and game theory to explain why we appreciate the Golden Rule ("Do unto others..."), why we sometimes ignore it and why there’s hope that, in the near future, we might all have the compassion to follow it.  The Charter for Compassion,charter for compassion,compassion,evolution,global issues  The evolution of compassion
text.434: We worry that IM, texting, Facebook are spoiling human intimacy, but Stefana Broadbent's research shows how communication tech is capable of cultivating deeper relationships, bringing love across barriers like distance and workplace rules. Technology, History and Destiny,Unconventional Explanations,What Makes Us Happy?,anthropology,humanity,love,psychology,social media,society,sociology,technology  How the Internet enables intimacy
text.435: At TEDGlobal U, Cameron Sinclair shows the unreported cost of real estate megaprojects gone bust: thousands of migrant construction laborers left stranded and penniless. To his fellow architects, he says there is only one ethical response. Architectural Inspiration,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,TED Conference,business,cities,design,global issues,social change,technology  The refugees of boom-and-bust
text.436: In 4 minutes, atmospheric chemist Rachel Pike provides a glimpse of the massive scientific effort behind the bold headlines on climate change, with her team -- one of thousands who contributed -- taking a risky flight over the rainforest in pursuit of data on a key molecule. To Boldly Go ...,The Rise of Collaboration,chemistry,climate change,environment,global issues,science,weather  The science behind a climate headline
text.437: In stunning large-format photographs, Edward Burtynsky follows the path of oil through modern society, from wellhead to pipeline to car engine -- and then beyond to the projected peak-oil endgame. Technology, History and Destiny,Media With Meaning,TED Prize,design,energy,global issues,photography,technology  Photographing the landscape of oil
text.438: Cynthia Schneider looks at two international "American Idol"-style shows -- one in Afghanistan, and one in the United Arab Emirates -- and shows the surprising effect that these reality-TV competitions are creating in their societies. Unconventional Explanations,Media With Meaning,culture,entertainment,global issues,poetry,politics  The surprising spread of Idol TV
text.439: At TEDIndia, Pranav Mistry demos several tools that help the physical world interact with the world of data -- including a deep look at his SixthSense device and a new, paradigm-shifting paper "laptop." In an onstage Q&A, Mistry says he'll open-source the software behind SixthSense, to open its possibilities to all. The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Design That Matters,demo,design,open-source,technology  The thrilling potential of SixthSense technology
text.440: Devdutt Pattanaik takes an eye-opening look at the myths of India and of the West -- and shows how these two fundamentally different sets of beliefs about God, death and heaven help us consistently misunderstand one another. Is There a God?,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,business,culture,global issues  East vs. West -- the myths that mystify
text.441:
At TEDIndia, Mallika Sarabhai, a dancer/actor/politician, tells a  
transformative story in dance -- and argues that the arts may be the  
most powerful way to effect change, whether political, social or  
personal. The Creative Spark,Presentation Innovation,Master Storytellers,culture,dance,entertainment,global issues,politics,social change  Dance to change the world
text.442: India is fast becoming a superpower, says Shashi Tharoor -- not just through trade and politics, but through "soft" power, its ability to share its culture with the world through food, music, technology, Bollywood. He argues that in the long run it's not the size of the army that matters as much as a country's ability to influence the world's hearts and minds. Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,business,culture,entertainment,global issues,politics,writing  Why nations should pursue soft power
text.443: Naming science as his chief inspiration, Mathieu Lehanneur shows a selection of his ingenious designs -- an interactive noise-neutralizing ball, an antibiotic course in one layered pill, asthma treatment that reminds kids to take it, a living air filter, a living-room fish farm and more. The Creative Spark,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Tales of Invention,Design That Matters,design,disease,green,innovation,nature,product design,science,technology  Science-inspired design
text.444: Leadership doesn't have a user's manual, but Fields Wicker-Miurin says stories of remarkable, local leaders are the next best thing. At a TED salon in London, she shares three. The Rise of Collaboration,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,arts,environment,global issues,leadership,politics,women in business  Learning from leadership's missing manual
text.445: Rather than demo another new technology, Tom Wujec reaches back to one of our earliest but most ingenious devices -- the astrolabe. With thousands of uses, from telling time to mapping the night sky, this old tech reminds us that the ancient can be as brilliant as the brand-new. The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,Design That Matters,Peering into Space,Unconventional Explanations,astronomy,history,innovation,science,technology  Learn to use the 13th-century astrolabe
text.446: Hans Rosling was a young guest student in India when he first realized that Asia had all the capacities to reclaim its place as the world's dominant economic force. At TEDIndia, he graphs global economic growth since 1858 and predicts the exact date that India and China will outstrip the US. Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Numbers at Play,Asia,economics,health,statistics,technology,visualizations  Asia's rise -- how and when
text.447: Rob Hopkins reminds us that the oil our world depends on is steadily running out. He proposes a unique solution to this problem -- the Transition response, where we prepare ourselves for life without oil and sacrifice our luxuries to build systems and communities that are completely independent of fossil fuels.  What's Next in Tech,A Greener Future?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,big problems,cities,energy,environment,future,green,pollution,sustainability,technology  Transition to a world without oil
text.448: Architecture student Magnus Larsson details his bold plan to transform the harsh Sahara desert using bacteria and a surprising construction material: the sand itself. Architectural Inspiration,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Africa,architecture,bacteria,biology,design,sustainability,water  Turning dunes into architecture
text.449: Can the interests of an individual nation be reconciled with humanity's greater good? Can a patriotic, nationally elected politician really give people in other countries equal consideration? Following his TEDTalk calling for a global ethic, UK Prime Minister Gordon Brown fields questions from TED Curator Chris Anderson. A Greener Future?,The Rise of Collaboration,Rethinking Poverty,Europe,big problems,environment,global issues,government,interview,politics,war  Global ethic vs. national interest
text.450: With new data from the Keck telescopes, Andrea Ghez shows how state-of-the-art adaptive optics are helping astronomers understand our universe's most mysterious objects: black holes. She shares evidence that a supermassive black hole may be lurking at the center of the Milky Way. What's Next in Tech,Peering into Space,astronomy,dark matter,exploration,physics,science,space,technology  The hunt for a supermassive black hole
text.451: With wisdom and wit, Anupam Mishra talks about the amazing feats of engineering built centuries ago by the people of India's Golden Desert to harvest water. These structures are still used today -- and are often superior to modern water megaprojects. The Creative Spark,A Greener Future?,Tales of Invention,Rethinking Poverty,Unconventional Explanations,architecture,design,environment,history,innovation,photography,sustainability,water  The ancient ingenuity of water harvesting
text.452: Sunitha Krishnan has dedicated her life to rescuing women and children from sex slavery, a multimilion-dollar global market. In this courageous talk, she tells three powerful stories, as well as her own, and calls for a more humane approach to helping these young victims rebuild their lives. Rethinking Poverty,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Asia,Slavery,children,global issues,poverty,sex,trafficking,women  The fight against sex slavery
text.453: Scottish funnyman Rory Bremner convenes a historic council on the TEDGlobal stage -- as he lampoons Gordon Brown, Barack Obama, George W. Bush and a cast of other world leaders with his hilarious impressions and biting commentary. See if you can catch a few sharp TED in-jokes. Spectacular Performance,Whipsmart Comedy,comedy,global issues,government,performance,politics  A one-man world summit
text.454: Marc Pachter has conducted live interviews with some of the most intriguing characters in recent American history as part of a remarkable series created for the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery. He reveals the secret to a great interview and shares extraordinary stories of talking with Steve Martin, Clare Booth Luce and more.   Art Unusual,Master Storytellers,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,art,history,performance,personal growth  The art of the interview
text.455: India's revolutionary Aravind Eye Care System has given sight to millions. Thulasiraj Ravilla looks at the ingenious approach that drives its treatment costs down and quality up, and why its methods should trigger a re-think of all human services. Rethinking Poverty,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,Medicine Without Borders,design,health,health care,humanity,medicine,public health,sight,technology  How low-cost eye care can be world-class
text.456: Shereen El Feki shows how some Arab cultures are borrowing trademarks of Western pop culture -- music videos, comics, even Barbie -- and adding a culturally appropriate twist. The hybridized media shows how two civilizations, rather than dividing, can dovetail. Media With Meaning,Women Reshaping the World,Talks from TED Fellows,Egypt,culture,entertainment,global issues,media,music  Pop culture in the Arab world
text.457: Loretta Napoleoni details her rare opportunity to talk to the secretive Italian Red Brigades -- an experience that sparked a lifelong interest in terrorism. She gives a behind-the-scenes look at its complex economics, revealing a surprising connection between money laundering and the US Patriot Act.  Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,corruption,economics,global issues,money,terrorism  The intricate economics of terrorism
text.458: Ryan Lobo has traveled the world, taking photographs that tell stories of unusual human lives. In this haunting talk, he reframes controversial subjects with empathy, so that we see the pain of a Liberian war criminal, the quiet strength of UN women peacekeepers and the perseverance of Delhi's underappreciated firefighters. The Creative Spark,Art Unusual,Master Storytellers,Media With Meaning,Asia,art,humanity,photography,storytelling,third world,war  Photographing the hidden story
text.459: In a funny, rapid-fire 4 minutes, Alexis Ohanian of Reddit tells the real-life fable of one humpback whale's rise to Web stardom. The lesson of Mister Splashy Pants is a shoo-in classic for meme-makers and marketers in the Facebook age. Animals That Amaze,Presentation Innovation,Not Business as Usual,Ocean Wonders,Internet,animals,business,culture,entertainment,entrepreneur,oceans,web  How to make a splash in social media
text.460: Shaffi Mather explains why he left his first career to become a social entrepreneur, providing life-saving transportation with his company 1298 for Ambulance. Now, he has a new idea and plans to begin a company to fight the booming business of corruption in public service, eliminating it one bribe at a time. Tales of Invention,Rethinking Poverty,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,Talks from TED Fellows,Asia,TED Fellows,crime,entrepreneur,potential,poverty,social change,society  A new way to fight corruption
text.461: Physicist Steven Cowley is certain that nuclear fusion is the only truly sustainable solution to the fuel crisis. He explains why fusion will work -- and details the projects that he and many others have devoted their lives to, working against the clock to create a new source of energy. A Greener Future?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,alternative energy,climate change,energy,environment,physics  Fusion is energy's future
text.462: For the dawn of a new decade, adventurer Bertrand Piccard offers us a challenge: Find motivation in what seems impossible. He shares his own plans to do what many say can't be done -- to fly around the world, day and night, in a solar-powered aircraft. A Greener Future?,Tales of Invention,To Boldly Go ...,adventure,aircraft,engineering,green,solar energy,technology  My solar-powered adventure
text.463: Neuroscientist Vilayanur Ramachandran outlines the fascinating functions of mirror neurons. Only recently discovered, these neurons allow us to learn complex social behaviors, some of which formed the foundations of human civilization as we know it.  Evolution's Genius,How the Mind Works,Unconventional Explanations,How We Learn,biology,brain,cities,cognitive science,evolution,neurology,science  The neurons that shaped civilization
text.464: Nick Veasey shows outsized X-ray images that reveal the otherworldly inner workings of familiar objects -- from the geometry of a wildflower to the anatomy of a Boeing 747. Producing these photos is dangerous and painstaking, but the reward is a superpower: looking at what the human eye can't see. The Creative Spark,Inspired by Nature,Art Unusual,art,nature,photography,science  Exposing the invisible
text.465: To find the path to long life and health, Dan Buettner and team study the world's "Blue Zones," communities whose elders live with vim and vigor to record-setting age. In his talk, he shares the 9 common diet and lifestyle habits that keep them spry past age 100. Unconventional Explanations,What Makes Us Happy?,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,TEDx,biology,culture,exploration,food,health,life,science  How to live to be 100+
text.466: The gharial and king cobra are two of India's most iconic reptiles, and they're endangered because of polluted waterways. Conservationist Romulus Whitaker shows rare footage of these magnificent animals and urges us to save the rivers that sustain their lives and our own. Animals That Amaze,A Greener Future?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,animals,biodiversity,biosphere,environment,water  The real danger lurking in the water
text.467: Traditionally, the Kalandar community of India has survived by capturing sloth bear cubs and training them to "dance" through extreme cruelty. Kartick Satyanarayan has been able to put an end to this centuries-old practice, and in so doing discovered a lesson of wider significance: make the practitioners part of the solution. Animals That Amaze,A Greener Future?,Rethinking Poverty,Talks from TED Fellows,activism,animals,biodiversity,biosphere,environment  How we rescued the "dancing" bears"
text.468: Kiran Bir Sethi shows how her groundbreaking Riverside School in India teaches kids life's most valuable lesson: "I can." Watch her students take local issues into their own hands, lead other young people, even educate their parents. The Creative Spark,Rethinking Poverty,How We Learn,Women Reshaping the World,Listening to Teachers,children,education,leadership,social change,society  Kids, take charge
text.469: As of 2005, only 15 percent of the world was mapped. This slows the delivery of aid after a disaster -- and hides the economic potential of unused lands and unknown roads. In this short talk, Google's Lalitesh Katragadda demos Map Maker, a group map-making tool that people around the globe are using to map their world. The Rise of Collaboration,Design That Matters,TED in 3 Minutes,cities,collaboration,design,map,technology  Making maps to fight disaster, build economies
text.470: In a presentation that can only be described as epic, comedian Charles Fleischer delivers a hysterical send-up of a time-honored TED theme: the map. Geometry, numbers, charts and stamp art also factor in (somehow), as he weaves together a unique theory of everything called "Moleeds." Presentation Innovation,Peering into Space,Unconventional Explanations,Whipsmart Comedy,TED Conference,astronomy,comedy,humor,map,science  All things are Moleeds
text.471: Collector Ravin Agrawal delivers a glowing introduction to 10 of India's most exciting young contemporary artists. Working in a variety of media, each draws on their local culture for inspiration. The Creative Spark,Art Unusual,Asia,art,arts,design,future  10 young Indian artists to watch
text.472: Anthony Atala's state-of-the-art lab grows human organs -- from muscles to blood vessels to bladders, and more. At TEDMED, he shows footage of his bio-engineers working with some of its sci-fi gizmos, including an oven-like bioreactor (preheat to 98.6 F) and a machine that "prints" human tissue. What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,Medicine Without Borders,biology,health,medicine,science,technology  Growing new organs
text.473:
Joshua Prince-Ramus believes that if architects re-engineer their design process, the results can be spectacular. In his talk, he walks us through his fantastic re-creation of the local Wyly Theater as a giant "theatrical machine" that reconfigures itself at the touch of a button.
(Filmed at TEDxSMU.) The Creative Spark,Architectural Inspiration,Design That Matters,architecture,arts,creativity,design,theater  Building a theater that remakes itself
text.474: In this passionate talk, Eve Ensler declares that there is a girl cell in us all -- a cell that we have all been taught to suppress. She tells heartfelt stories of girls around the world who have overcome shocking adversity and violence to reveal the astonishing strength of being a girl.  The Creative Spark,Rethinking Poverty,Master Storytellers,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,culture,feminism,gender,self,social change,women,yesallwomen  Embrace your inner girl
text.475: In the developing world, access to incubators is limited by cost and distance, and millions of premature babies die each year. TED Fellow Jane Chen shows an invention that could keep millions of these infants warm -- a design that's safe, portable, low-cost and life-saving. Tales of Invention,Rethinking Poverty,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Fellows,children,design,entrepreneur,health,innovation,invention,medicine  A warm embrace that saves lives
text.476: "There's a flip side to everything," the saying goes, and in 2 minutes, Derek Sivers shows this is true in a few ways you might not expect. The Power of Cities,Unconventional Explanations,business,creativity,map  Weird, or just different?
text.477: MacArthur winner Sendhil Mullainathan uses the lens of behavioral economics to study a tricky set of social problems -- those we know how to solve, but don't. We know how to reduce child deaths due to diarrhea, how to prevent diabetes-related blindness and how to implement solar-cell technology ... yet somehow, we don't or can't. Why? How the Mind Works,big problems,brain,economics,global issues,health,sanitation,technology,women  Solving social problems with a nudge
text.478: Traditional lab tests for disease diagnosis can be too expensive and cumbersome for the regions most in need. George Whitesides' ingenious answer is a foolproof tool that can be manufactured at virtually zero cost. What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Rethinking Poverty,Design That Matters,TEDx,chemistry,development,disease,poverty,science,technology  A lab the size of a postage stamp
text.479: Too often, says David Agus cancer treatments have a short-sighted focus on individual cells. He suggests a new, cross-disciplinary approach, using atypical drugs, computer modeling and protein analysis to diagnose and treat the whole body. Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,Medicine Without Borders,cancer,health,health care,medicine,technology  A new strategy in the war on cancer
text.480: TED visits Tom Shannon in his Manhattan studio for an intimate look at his science-inspired art. An eye-opening, personal conversation with John Hockenberry reveals how nature's forces -- and the onset of Parkinson's tremors -- interact in his life and craft. The Creative Spark,Inspired by Nature,Art Unusual,art,astronomy,creativity,illness,science,space  The painter and the pendulum
text.481: In a demo that drew gasps at TED2010, Blaise Aguera y Arcas demos new augmented-reality mapping technology from Microsoft. The Creative Spark,TED Conference,cities,design,map,technology  Augmented-reality maps
text.482: At TED2010, Bill Gates unveils his vision for the world's energy future, describing the need for "miracles" to avoid planetary catastrophe and explaining why he's backing a dramatically different type of nuclear reactor. The necessary goal? Zero carbon emissions globally by 2050. What's Next in Tech,A Greener Future?,Technology, History and Destiny,TED Conference,business,energy,global issues,invention,science,technology  Innovating to zero!
text.483: The leader of Britain's Conservative Party says we're entering a new era -- where governments themselves have less power (and less money) and people empowered by technology have more. Tapping into new ideas on behavioral economics, he explores how these trends could be turned into smarter policy. Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,TED Conference,business,global issues,politics  The next age of government
text.484: The thesaurus might equate "disabled" with synonyms like "useless" and "mutilated," but ground-breaking runner Aimee Mullins is out to redefine the word. Defying these associations, she shows how adversity -- in her case, being born without shinbones -- actually opens the door for human potential. Master Storytellers,Unconventional Explanations,activism,happiness,health,prosthetics,social change,society  The opportunity of adversity
text.485: The land of the free has become a legal minefield, says Philip K. Howard -- especially for teachers and doctors, whose work has been paralyzed by fear of suits. What's the answer? A lawyer himself, Howard has four propositions for simplifying US law. Not Business as Usual,TED Conference,business,design,health care,law  Four ways to fix a broken legal system
text.486: Eric Topol says we'll soon use our smartphones to monitor our vital signs and chronic conditions. At TEDMED, he highlights several of the most important wireless devices in medicine's future -- all helping to keep more of us out of hospital beds. What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Unconventional Explanations,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,disease,health,health care,medicine,technology  The wireless future of medicine
text.487: Temple Grandin, diagnosed with autism as a child, talks about how her mind works -- sharing her ability to "think in pictures," which helps her solve problems that neurotypical brains might miss. She makes the case that the world needs people on the autism spectrum: visual thinkers, pattern thinkers, verbal thinkers, and all kinds of smart geeky kids. How the Mind Works,Tales of Invention,TED Conference,animals,brain,design,education,invention,mental health,science,technology  The world needs all kinds of minds
text.488: Pawan Sinha details his groundbreaking research into how the brain's visual system develops. Sinha and his team provide free vision-restoring treatment to children born blind, and then study how their brains learn to interpret visual data. The work offers insights into neuroscience, engineering and even autism. How the Mind Works,Rethinking Poverty,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,biology,health care,medicine,neurology,science,sight  How brains learn to see
text.489: Using examples from vacations to colonoscopies, Nobel laureate and founder of behavioral economics Daniel Kahneman reveals how our "experiencing selves" and our "remembering selves" perceive happiness differently. This new insight has profound implications for economics, public policy -- and our own self-awareness. How the Mind Works,Master Storytellers,Unconventional Explanations,What Makes Us Happy?,TED Conference,brain,culture,economics,happiness,mind,philosophy,psychology,science  The riddle of experience vs. memory
text.490: Gary Flake demos Pivot, a new way to browse and arrange massive amounts of images and data online. Built on breakthrough Seadragon technology, it enables spectacular zooms in and out of web databases, and  the discovery of patterns and links invisible in standard web browsing. What's Next in Tech,TED Conference,data,demo,interface design,technology,web  Is Pivot a turning point for web exploration?
text.491: James Cameron's big-budget (and even bigger-grossing) films create unreal worlds all their own. In this personal talk, he reveals his childhood fascination with the fantastic -- from reading science fiction to deep-sea diving -- and how it ultimately drove the success of his blockbuster hits "Aliens," "The Terminator," "Titanic" and "Avatar." The Creative Spark,Inspired by Nature,Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,Master Storytellers,Ocean Wonders,TED Conference,adventure,entertainment,film,nature,oceans,storytelling,submarine,technology,writing  Before Avatar ... a curious boy
text.492: The LXD (the Legion of Extraordinary Dancers) electrify the TED2010 stage with an emerging global street-dance culture, revved up by the Internet.  In a preview of Jon Chu’s upcoming Web series, this astonishing troupe show off their superpowers. Spectacular Performance,TED Conference,art,arts,collaboration,dance,entertainment,gaming  In the Internet age, dance evolves ...
text.493: At TED2009, Tim Berners-Lee called for "raw data now" -- for governments, scientists and institutions to make their data openly available on the web. At TED University in 2010, he shows a few of the interesting results when the data gets linked up. What's Next in Tech,The Rise of Collaboration,Internet,TED Conference,computers,statistics,visualizations,web  The year open data went worldwide
text.494: Fifty percent of traffic accidents happen at intersections. Gary Lauder shares a brilliant and cheap idea for helping drivers move along smoothly: a new traffic sign that combines the properties of "Stop" and "Yield." Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,TED Conference,cities,culture,design,transportation  Take Turns
text.495: Chef Dan Barber squares off with a dilemma facing many chefs today: how to keep fish on the menu. With impeccable research and deadpan humor, he chronicles his pursuit of a sustainable fish he could love, and the foodie's honeymoon he's enjoyed since discovering an outrageously delicious fish raised using a revolutionary farming method in Spain. Animals That Amaze,What's Next in Tech,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Master Storytellers,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,Food Matters,TED Conference,agriculture,biology,environment,food,health  How I fell in love with a fish
text.496: The second deadliest day in the history of Mount Everest climbs happened in 1996 -- and Ken Kamler was the only doctor on the mountain that day. He shares the incredible story of the climbers' battle to save lives in extreme conditions, and uses brain imaging technology to map the medical miracle of one man who survived roughly 36 hours buried in the snow.  Inspired by Nature,To Boldly Go ...,Master Storytellers,adventure,biology,exploration,humanity,medicine,science,weather  Medical miracle on Everest
text.497: Sugar pills, injections of nothing -- studies show that, more often than you'd expect, placebos really work. At TEDMED, magician Eric Mead does a trick to prove that, even when you know something's not real, you can still react as powerfully as if it is. (Warning: This talk is not suitable for viewers who are disturbed by needles or blood.) The Creative Spark,How the Mind Works,Spectacular Performance,Master Storytellers,entertainment,illusion,magic,medicine,science  The magic of the placebo
text.498: Mark Roth studies suspended animation: the art of shutting down life processes and then starting them up again. It's wild stuff, but it's not science fiction. Induced by careful use of an otherwise toxic gas, suspended animation can potentially help trauma and heart attack victims survive long enough to be treated. Medicine Without Borders,TED Conference,biology,fish,health care,science,war  Suspended animation is within our grasp
text.499: Games like World of Warcraft give players the means to save worlds, and incentive to learn the habits of heroes. What if we could harness this gamer power to solve real-world problems? Jane McGonigal says we can, and explains how. What's Next in Tech,Art Unusual,The Rise of Collaboration,Design That Matters,Media With Meaning,TED Conference,computers,design,entertainment,gaming,global issues,play  Gaming can make a better world
text.500: Where does creative inspiration spring from? At TEDIndia, Hollywood/Bollywood director Shekhar Kapur ("Elizabeth," "Mr. India") pinpoints his source of creativity: sheer, utter panic. He shares a powerful way to unleash your inner storyteller. The Creative Spark,arts,creativity,entertainment,film  We are the stories we tell ourselves
text.501: Questions of good and evil, right and wrong are commonly thought unanswerable by science. But Sam Harris argues that science can -- and should -- be an authority on moral issues, shaping human values and setting out what constitutes a good life. Is There a God?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,TED Conference,culture,global issues,morality,philosophy,psychology,religion,science  Science can answer moral questions
text.502: Tax forms, credit agreements, healthcare legislation: They're crammed with gobbledygook, says Alan Siegel, and incomprehensibly long. He calls for a simple, sensible redesign -- and plain English -- to make legal paperwork intelligible to the rest of us. Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,Words About Words,TED Conference,business,language,law,simplicity  Let's simplify legal jargon!
text.503:
In this talk, planetary scientist Joel Levine shows some intriguing -- and puzzling -- new discoveries about Mars: craters full of ice, traces of ancient oceans, and compelling hints at the presence, sometime in the past, of life. He makes the case for going back to Mars to find out more.
(Filmed at TEDxNASA.) Peering into Space,Planets,TEDx,exploration,life,science,space,technology  Why we need to go back to Mars
text.504: Robert Gupta, violinist with the LA Philharmonic, talks about a violin lesson he once gave to a brilliant, schizophrenic musician -- and what he learned. Called back onstage later, Gupta plays his own transcription of the prelude from Bach's Cello Suite No. 1. The Creative Spark,How the Mind Works,Spectacular Performance,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Conference,TED Fellows,arts,brain,education,entertainment,live music,mental health,music,violin  Music is medicine, music is sanity
text.505: In this moving yet pragmatic talk, Kevin Bales explains the business of modern slavery, a multibillion-dollar economy that underpins some of the worst industries on earth. He shares stats and personal stories from his on-the-ground research -- and names the price of freeing every slave on earth right now. Rethinking Poverty,Slavery,TED Conference,business,economics,global issues,humanity,trafficking  How to combat modern slavery
text.506: Educating the poor is more than just a numbers game, says Shukla Bose. She tells the story of her groundbreaking Parikrma Humanity Foundation, which brings hope to India's slums by looking past the daunting statistics and focusing on treating each child as an individual. The Power of Cities,Rethinking Poverty,Listening to Teachers,children,development,education,poverty  Teaching one child at a time
text.507: How many of today's headlines will matter in 100 years? 1000?
