Kirk Citron's "Long News" project collects stories that not only matter today, but will resonate for decades -- even centuries -- to come. At TED2010, he highlights recent headlines with the potential to shape our future.  Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,Words About Words,Media With Meaning,TED Conference,future,global issues,media,news,science  And now, the real news
text.508: With help from some surprising footage, Derek Sivers explains how movements really get started. (Hint: it takes two.) The Creative Spark,TED Conference,business,dance,entertainment,leadership,marketing,online video  How to start a movement
text.509: Child prodigy Adora Svitak says the world needs "childish" thinking: bold ideas, wild creativity and especially optimism. Kids' big dreams deserve high expectations, she says, starting with grownups' willingness to learn from children as much as to teach. The Creative Spark,Unconventional Explanations,How We Learn,TED Conference,children,creativity,education,intelligence  What adults can learn from kids
text.510: Soldiers who've lost limbs in service face a daily struggle unimaginable to most of us. At TEDMED, Dean Kamen talks about the profound people and stories that motivated his work to give parts of their lives back with his design for a remarkable prosthetic arm. What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Design That Matters,Medicine Without Borders,design,health,health care,medicine,prosthetics,technology,war  The emotion behind invention
text.511: Pollen goes unnoticed by most of us, except when hay fever strikes. But microscopes reveal it comes in stunning colors and shapes -- and travels remarkably well. Jonathan Drori gives an up-close glimpse of these fascinating flecks of plant courtship. Evolution's Genius,Inspired by Nature,TED Conference,bees,biology,botany,environment,life,sex  Every pollen grain has a story
text.512: Natalie Merchant sings from her new album, Leave Your Sleep. Lyrics from near-forgotten 19th-century poetry pair with her unmistakable voice for a performance that brought the TED audience to its feet. Spectacular Performance,Live Music,TED Conference,literature,music,performance,poetry  Singing old poems to life
text.513: Vaccine-autism claims, "Frankenfood" bans, the herbal cure craze: All point to the public's growing fear (and, often, outright denial) of science and reason, says Michael Specter. He warns the trend spells disaster for human progress. What's Next in Tech,To Boldly Go ...,Is There a God?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Technology, History and Destiny,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,Medicine Without Borders,TED Conference,global issues,medicine,religion,science,writing  The danger of science denial
text.514: Photographs do more than document history -- they make it. At TED University, Jonathan Klein of Getty Images shows some of the most iconic, and talks about what happens when a generation sees an image so powerful it can't look away -- or back. The Creative Spark,Presentation Innovation,Rethinking Poverty,Master Storytellers,TED Conference,global issues,media,photography,poverty,war  Photos that changed the world
text.515: In a short, funny, data-packed talk at TED U, Catherine Mohr walks through all the geeky decisions she made when building a green new house -- looking at real energy numbers, not hype. What choices matter most? Not the ones you think. Architectural Inspiration,TED Conference,business,culture,green,technology  The tradeoffs of building green
text.516: Underwater filmmaker Mike deGruy has spent decades looking intimately at the ocean. A consummate storyteller, he takes the stage at Mission Blue to share his awe and excitement -- and his fears -- about the blue heart of our planet. Animals That Amaze,Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,arts,entertainment,film,fish,global issues,oceans,science,submarine  Hooked by an octopus
text.517: Thelma Golden, curator at the Studio Museum in Harlem, talks through three recent shows that explore how art examines and redefines culture. The "post-black" artists she works with are using their art to provoke a new dialogue about race and culture -- and about the meaning of art itself. The Creative Spark,Art Unusual,TED Conference,art,arts,cities,culture,design,entertainment,race  How art gives shape to cultural change
text.518: Legendary skeptic James Randi takes a fatal dose of homeopathic sleeping pills onstage, kicking off a searing 18-minute indictment of irrational beliefs. He throws out a challenge to the world's psychics: Prove what you do is real, and I'll give you a million dollars. (No takers yet.) Master Storytellers,Unconventional Explanations,TED Conference,culture,health,magic,science  Homeopathy, quackery and fraud
text.519: Drugs alone can't stop disease in sub-Saharan Africa: We need diagnostic tools to match. TED Senior Fellow Frederick Balagadde shows how we can multiply the power and availability of an unwieldy, expensive diagnostic lab -- by miniaturizing it to the size of a chip. What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Rethinking Poverty,TED Conference,TED Fellows,biology,engineering,invention,microbiology  Bio-lab on a microchip
text.520: Tom Wujec presents some surprisingly deep research into the "marshmallow problem" -- a simple team-building exercise that involves dry spaghetti, one yard of tape and a marshmallow. Who can build the tallest tower with these ingredients? And why does a surprising group always beat the average? Not Business as Usual,TED Conference,business,collaboration,culture,design,entertainment,psychology  Build a tower, build a team
text.521: Want your local politician to pay attention to an issue you care about? Take this tip from Omar Ahmad, the beloved former mayor of San Carlos, California: Send a monthly handwritten letter. Old-fashioned correspondence, he shows, is more effective than email, phone -- or even writing a check. Listen for his four simple steps to writing a letter that works. Master Storytellers,Media With Meaning,TED Conference,business,culture,democracy,politics,social change  Political change with pen and paper
text.522: Stephen Wolfram, creator of Mathematica, talks about his quest to make all knowledge computational -- able to be searched, processed and manipulated. His new search engine, Wolfram Alpha, has no lesser goal than to model and explain the physics underlying the universe. Evolution's Genius,What's Next in Tech,Inspired by Nature,Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,Numbers at Play,String theory,TED Conference,biology,complexity,computers,math,physics,science,simplicity  Computing a theory of all knowledge
text.523: Five years ago, Roz Savage quit her high-powered London job to become an ocean rower. She's crossed the Atlantic solo, and just started the third leg of a Pacific solo row, the first for a woman. Why does she do it? Hear her reasons, both deeply personal and urgently activist. To Boldly Go ...,Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,adventure,entertainment,global issues,goal-setting,oceans  Why I'm rowing across the Pacific
text.524: Simplicity: We know it when we see it -- but what is it, exactly? In this funny, philosophical talk, George Whitesides chisels out an answer. The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Inspired by Nature,Tales of Invention,Design That Matters,Technology, History and Destiny,Medicine Without Borders,TED Conference,chemistry,complexity,design,history,simplicity,technology  Toward a science of simplicity
text.525: In a brilliantly tongue-in-cheek analysis, Sebastian Wernicke turns the tools of statistical analysis on TEDTalks, to come up with a metric for creating "the optimum TEDTalk" based on user ratings. How do you rate it? "Jaw-dropping"? "Unconvincing"? Or just plain "Funny"? Unconventional Explanations,Words About Words,TED Conference,comedy,entertainment,statistics  Lies, damned lies and statistics (about TEDTalks)
text.526:
Alleviating poverty is more guesswork than science, and lack of data on aid's impact raises questions about how to provide it. But Clark Medal-winner Esther Duflo says it's possible to know which development efforts help and which hurt -- by testing solutions with randomized trials.
 Rethinking Poverty,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,TED Conference,big problems,cities,economics,poverty,third world  Social experiments to fight poverty
text.527: To write his first studio album in decades, "A Map of the Floating City," Thomas Dolby has been working in the inspirational setting of a restored lifeboat. At TED2010 he premieres a gorgeous, evocative song from that album -- about one night with a legend. He's backed by members of the modern string quartet Ethel. The Creative Spark,TED Conference,entertainment,history,live music,music  "Love Is a Loaded Pistol"
text.528: In this bracing talk, coral reef ecologist Jeremy Jackson lays out the shocking state of the ocean today: overfished, overheated, polluted, with indicators that things will get much worse. Astonishing photos and stats make the case. Inspired by Nature,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,fish,green,mission blue,oceans,science  How we wrecked the ocean
text.529: Anil Gupta is on the hunt for the developing world's unsung inventors -- indigenous entrepreneurs whose ingenuity, hidden by poverty, could change many people's lives. He shows how the Honey Bee Network helps them build the connections they need -- and gain the recognition they deserve. The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Rethinking Poverty,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,creativity,entrepreneur,innovation,invention,poverty  India's hidden hotbeds of invention
text.530: We're all embedded in vast social networks of friends, family, co-workers and more. Nicholas Christakis tracks how a wide variety of traits -- from happiness to obesity -- can spread from person to person, showing how your location in the network might impact your life in ways you don't even know. Evolution's Genius,The Rise of Collaboration,Unconventional Explanations,Medicine Without Borders,TED Conference,evolution,health,medicine,obesity,science,society  The hidden influence of social networks
text.531: Nathan Myhrvold and team's latest inventions -- as brilliant as they are bold -- remind us that the world needs wild creativity to tackle big problems like malaria. And just as that idea sinks in, he rolls out a live demo of a new, mosquito-zapping gizmo you have to see to believe. The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,TED Conference,creativity,disease,innovation,insects,invention,poverty,technology  Could this laser zap malaria?
text.532: Enric Sala shares glorious images -- and surprising insights and data -- from some of the most pristine areas of the ocean. He shows how we can restore more of our oceans to this healthy, balanced state, and the powerful ecological and economic benefits of doing so. Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,economics,fish,mission blue,oceans,science  Glimpses of a pristine ocean
text.533:
Despite her best efforts, comedian Julia Sweeney is forced to tell a little white lie when her 8-year-old begins learning about frog reproduction -- and starts to ask some very smart questions.
 The Creative Spark,Master Storytellers,Whipsmart Comedy,TED Conference,children,comedy,humor,relationships,sex  It's time for "The Talk"
text.534: William Li presents a new way to think about treating cancer and other diseases: anti-angiogenesis, preventing the growth of blood vessels that feed a tumor. The crucial first (and best) step: Eating cancer-fighting foods that cut off the supply lines and beat cancer at its own game. Medicine Without Borders,TED Conference,cancer,food,medicine,science,technology  Can we eat to starve cancer?
text.535: We all know the arguments that being vegetarian is better for the environment and for the animals -- but in a carnivorous culture, it can be hard to make the change. Graham Hill has a powerful, pragmatic suggestion: Be a weekday veg. A Greener Future?,Food Matters,TED Conference,culture,food,global issues,green  Why I'm a weekday vegetarian
text.536: Think of penguins as ocean sentinels, says Dee Boersma -- they're on the frontlines of sea change. Sharing stories of penguin life and culture, she suggests that we start listening to what penguins are telling us. Animals That Amaze,Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,animals,global issues,mission blue,oceans,science  Pay attention to penguins
text.537: As the world's attention focuses on the perils of oil exploration, we present Richard Sears' talk from early February 2010. Sears, an expert in developing new energy resources, talks about our inevitable and necessary move away from oil. Toward ... what? Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,TED Conference,alternative energy,energy,exploration,green,science,technology  Planning for the end of oil
text.538: Craig Venter and team make a historic announcement: they've created the first fully functioning, reproducing cell controlled by synthetic DNA. He explains how they did it and why the achievement marks the beginning of a new era for science. Evolution's Genius,What's Next in Tech,Inspired by Nature,Tales of Invention,To Boldly Go ...,Medicine Without Borders,DNA,biology,business,genetics,life,science,technology  Watch me unveil "synthetic life"
text.539: In this poignant, funny follow-up to his fabled 2006 talk, Sir Ken Robinson makes the case for a radical shift from standardized schools to personalized learning -- creating conditions where kids' natural talents can flourish. The Creative Spark,How the Mind Works,The Rise of Collaboration,Master Storytellers,Whipsmart Comedy,How We Learn,TED Conference,children,creativity,education,invention  Bring on the learning revolution!
text.540: Copyright law's grip on film, music and software barely touches the fashion industry ... and fashion benefits in both innovation and sales, says Johanna Blakley. In her talk, she talks about what all creative industries can learn from fashion's free culture. The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,Women Reshaping the World,TEDx,business,creativity,culture,design,fashion,law,media  Lessons from fashion's free culture
text.541: Seth Berkley explains how smart advances in vaccine design, production and distribution are bringing us closer than ever to eliminating a host of global threats -- from AIDS to malaria to flu pandemics.  Tales of Invention,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,Medicine Without Borders,AIDS,TED Conference,Vaccines,epidemiology,global issues,health,medicine  HIV and flu -- the vaccine strategy
text.542: Former "young Republican" Larry Lessig talks about what Democrats can learn about copyright from their opposite party, considered more conservative. A surprising lens on remix culture.  The Creative Spark,The Rise of Collaboration,Internet,TEDx,law,music,online video,technology,web  Re-examining the remix
text.543: Minority Report science adviser and inventor John Underkoffler demos g-speak -- the real-life version of the film's eye-popping, tai chi-meets-cyberspace computer interface. Is this how tomorrow's computers will be controlled? What's Next in Tech,Presentation Innovation,Tales of Invention,Technology, History and Destiny,TED Conference,computers,design,interface design,invention,technology,visualizations  Pointing to the future of UI
text.544: Photographer Brian Skerry shoots life above and below the waves -- as he puts it, both the horror and the magic of the ocean. Sharing amazing, intimate shots of undersea creatures, he shows how powerful images can help make change. To Boldly Go ...,Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,fish,mission blue,oceans,photography,science  The ocean's glory -- and horror
text.545: The founder of 4chan, a controversial, uncensored online imageboard, describes its subculture, some of the Internet "memes" it has launched, and the incident in which its users managed a very public, precision hack of a mainstream media website. The talk raises questions about the power -- and price -- of anonymity. The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,Design That Matters,Media With Meaning,Internet,TED Conference,activism,collaboration,computers,culture,government,law,meme,web  The case for anonymity online
text.546:
The band OK Go dreamed up the idea of a massive Rube Goldberg machine for their next music video -- and Adam Sadowsky's team was charged with building it. He tells the story of the effort and engineering behind their labyrinthine creation that quickly became the YouTube sensation "This Too Shall Pass."
(Filmed at TEDxUSC.)  The Creative Spark,Art Unusual,The Rise of Collaboration,TEDx,art,arts,engineering,entertainment,music,online video,physics  How to engineer a viral music video
text.547: Democracy thrives on civil debate, Michael Sandel  says -- but we're shamefully out of practice. He leads a fun refresher, with TEDsters sparring over a recent Supreme Court case (PGA Tour, Inc. v. Martin) whose outcome reveals the critical ingredient in justice. Presentation Innovation,Unconventional Explanations,Words About Words,Media With Meaning,TED Conference,democracy,government,law,philosophy,politics,sports  The lost art of democratic debate
text.548: In his home of Namibia, John Kasaona is working on an innovative way to protect endangered animal species: giving nearby villagers (including former poachers) responsibility for caring for the animals. And it's working. Animals That Amaze,Africa: The Next Chapter,Africa,TED Conference,animals,biodiversity,global issues,green,science  How poachers became caretakers
text.549: Nuclear power: the energy crisis has even die-hard environmentalists reconsidering it. In this first-ever TED debate, Stewart Brand and Mark Z. Jacobson square off over the pros and cons. A discussion that'll make you think -- and might even change your mind. What's Next in Tech,A Greener Future?,Tales of Invention,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Design That Matters,Technology, History and Destiny,TED Conference,climate change,economics,energy,environment,green,law,nuclear weapons,politics,wind energy  Debate
text.550: Michael Shermer says the human tendency to believe strange things -- from alien abductions to dowsing rods -- boils down to two of the brain's most basic, hard-wired survival skills. He explains what they are, and how they get us into trouble. Evolution's Genius,How the Mind Works,How We Learn,God,TED Conference,faith,neurology,psychology,science,self  The pattern behind self-deception
text.551: Margaret Gould Stewart, YouTube's head of user experience, talks about how the ubiquitous video site works with copyright holders and creators to foster (at the best of times) a creative ecosystem where everybody wins. The Creative Spark,TED Conference,art,arts,business,creativity,culture,entertainment,law,online video,technology  How YouTube thinks about copyright
text.552: Peter Tyack of Woods Hole talks about a hidden wonder of the sea: underwater sound. Onstage at Mission Blue, he explains the amazing ways whales use sound and song to communicate across hundreds of miles of ocean. Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,animals,mission blue,oceans,science,singer  The intriguing sound of marine mammals
text.553: Renowned classical Indian dancer Ananda Shankar Jayant was diagnosed with cancer in 2008. She tells her personal story of not only facing the disease but dancing through it, and gives a performance revealing the metaphor of strength that helped her do it.  The Creative Spark,Spectacular Performance,Art Unusual,Master Storytellers,cancer,dance,music,performance,personal growth,storytelling  Fighting cancer with dance
text.554: When the dotcom bubble burst, hotelier Chip Conley went in search of a business model based on happiness. In an old friendship with an employee and in the wisdom of a Buddhist king, he learned that success comes from what you count. The Creative Spark,The Rise of Collaboration,Not Business as Usual,Buddhism,TED Conference,business,economics,happiness,money,psychology  Measuring what makes life worthwhile
text.555: In graphic design, Marian Bantjes says, throwing your individuality into a project is heresy. She explains how she built her career doing just that, bringing her signature delicate illustrations to storefronts, valentines and even genetic diagrams. The Creative Spark,Art Unusual,Design That Matters,Media With Meaning,TED Conference,art,design,innovation,typography  Intricate beauty by design
text.556: Charles Leadbeater went looking for radical new forms of education -- and found them in the slums of Rio and Kibera, where some of the world's poorest kids are finding transformative new ways to learn. And this informal, disruptive new kind of school, he says, is what all schools need to become. Unconventional Explanations,How We Learn,cities,education,global issues,innovation  Education innovation in the slums
text.557: Lego blocks: playtime mainstay for industrious kids, obsession for many (ahem!) mature adults. Hillel Cooperman takes us on a trip through the beloved bricks' colorful, sometimes oddball grownup subculture, featuring CAD, open-source robotics and a little adult behavior. The Creative Spark,Architectural Inspiration,What Makes Us Happy?,TED Conference,children,design,entertainment,entrepreneur,gaming,toy  Legos for grownups
text.558: Clay Shirky looks at "cognitive surplus" -- the shared, online work we do with our spare brain cycles. While we're busy editing Wikipedia, posting to Ushahidi (and yes, making LOLcats), we're building a better, more cooperative world. The Rise of Collaboration,Not Business as Usual,collaboration,community,culture,technology,wikipedia  How cognitive surplus will change the world
text.559: What's link between the ocean's health and our health? Marine biologist Stephen Palumbi shows how toxins at the bottom of the ocean food chain find their way into our bodies -- and tells a shocking story of toxic contamination in the fish market, where consumers were being tricked into buying fish that's not only mislabeled but unsafe. Evolution's Genius,Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,fish,health,mission blue,oceans,science  Hidden toxins in the fish we eat
text.560:
For the last 12 years, Carter Emmart has been coordinating the efforts of scientists, artists and programmers to build a complete 3D visualization of our known universe. He demos this stunning tour and explains how it's being shared with facilities around the world.
 The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Art Unusual,Peering into Space,TED Conference,art,astronomy,science,space,technology  A 3D atlas of the universe
text.561: TED Fellow and urban designer Mitchell Joachim presents his vision for sustainable, organic architecture: eco-friendly abodes grown from plants and -- wait for it -- meat. The Power of Cities,What's Next in Tech,Architectural Inspiration,A Greener Future?,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Conference,TED Fellows,architecture,design,environment,urban planning  Don't build your home, grow it!
text.562: At TED2010, mathematics legend Benoit Mandelbrot develops a theme he first discussed at TED in 1984 -- the extreme complexity of roughness, and the way that fractal math can find order within patterns that seem unknowably complicated. Numbers at Play,TED Conference,math  Fractals and the art of roughness
text.563: Nalini Nadkarni challenges our perspective on trees and prisons -- she says both can be more dynamic than we think. Through a partnership with the state of Washington, she brings science classes and conservation programs to inmates, with unexpected results. Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,The Rise of Collaboration,Rethinking Poverty,TED Conference,biosphere,crime,environment,nature,prison,social change,trees  Life science in prison
text.564: The world's population will grow to 9 billion over the next 50 years -- and only by raising the living standards of the poorest can we check population growth. This is the paradoxical answer that Hans Rosling unveils at TED@Cannes using colorful new data display technology (you'll see). Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,culture,data,demo,global issues,poverty,prediction,presentation  Global population growth, box by box
text.565:
The Gulf oil spill dwarfs comprehension, but we know this much: it's bad. Carl Safina scrapes out the facts in this blood-boiling cross-examination, arguing that the consequences will stretch far beyond the Gulf -- and many so-called solutions are making the situation worse.
(Filmed at TEDxOilSpill.) Animals That Amaze,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Ocean Wonders,TEDx,disaster relief,energy,environment,oceans,oil,pollution  The oil spill's unseen culprits, victims
text.566: At TEDGlobal 2010, author Matt Ridley shows how, throughout history, the engine of human progress has been the meeting and mating of ideas to make new ideas. It's not important how clever individuals are, he says; what really matters is how smart the collective brain is. The Creative Spark,The Power of Cities,A Greener Future?,Tales of Invention,The Rise of Collaboration,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Technology, History and Destiny,Unconventional Explanations,What Makes Us Happy?,business,collaboration,design,technology  When ideas have sex
text.567: Sure, the web connects the globe, but most of us end up hearing mainly from people just like ourselves. Blogger and technologist Ethan Zuckerman wants to help share the stories of the whole wide world. He talks about clever strategies to open up your Twitter world and read the news in languages you don't even know. Words About Words,Media With Meaning,communication,global issues,language,news,technology,web  Listening to global voices
text.568: Listening to stories widens the imagination; telling them lets us leap over cultural walls, embrace different experiences, feel what others feel. Elif Shafak builds on this simple idea to argue that fiction can overcome identity politics. The Creative Spark,Master Storytellers,culture,novel,politics,storytelling,women  The politics of fiction
text.569: Astronomer Dimitar Sasselov and his colleagues search for Earth-like planets that may, someday, help us answer centuries-old questions about the origin and existence of biological life elsewhere (and on Earth). Preliminary results show that they have found 706 "candidates" -- some of which further research may prove to be planets with Earth-like geochemical characteristics. Peering into Space,Planets,astronomy,biology,extraterrestrial life,life,technology,universe  How we found hundreds of potential Earth-like planets
text.570: Tan Le's astonishing new computer interface reads its user's brainwaves, making it possible to control virtual objects, and even physical electronics, with mere thoughts (and a little concentration). She demos the headset, and talks about its far-reaching applications. How the Mind Works,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,brain,computers,design,entertainment,interface design,mind,technology  A headset that reads your brainwaves
text.571: Arthritis and injury grind down millions of joints, but few get the best remedy -- real biological tissue. Kevin Stone shows a treatment that could sidestep the high costs and donor shortfall of human-to-human transplants with a novel use of animal tissue. What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Medicine Without Borders,TED Conference,biology,design,future,medicine,technology  The bio-future of joint replacement
text.572: Sheena Iyengar studies how we make choices -- and how we feel about the choices we make. At TEDGlobal, she talks about both trivial choices (Coke v. Pepsi) and profound ones, and shares her groundbreaking research that has uncovered some surprising attitudes about our decisions. How the Mind Works,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,business,choice,culture,decision-making,economics,psychology,social change,society  The art of choosing
text.573: Oceanographer John Delaney is leading the team that is building an underwater network of high-def cameras and sensors that will turn our ocean into a global interactive lab -- sparking an explosion of rich data about the world below. To Boldly Go ...,Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,mission blue,oceans,poetry,science,technology  Wiring an interactive ocean
text.574: Laurie Santos looks for the roots of human irrationality by watching the way our primate relatives make decisions. A clever series of experiments in "monkeynomics" shows that some of the silly choices we make, monkeys make too. Animals That Amaze,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,brain,business,design,economics,money,monkeys,psychology,science  A monkey economy as irrational as ours
text.575: Convince just 100 key companies to go sustainable, and WWF's Jason Clay says global markets will shift to protect the planet our consumption has already outgrown. Hear how his extraordinary roundtables are getting big brand rivals to agree on green practices first -- before their products duke it out on store shelves. Inspired by Nature,The Rise of Collaboration,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,business,environment,green,sustainability  How big brands can help save biodiversity
text.576: Sheryl WuDunn's book "Half the Sky" investigates the oppression of women globally. Her stories shock. Only when women in developing countries have equal access to education and economic opportunity will we be using all our human resources. Rethinking Poverty,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,Women Reshaping the World,Slavery,development,economics,education,feminism,poverty,trafficking,women,yesallwomen  Our century's greatest injustice
text.577: Peter Molyneux demos Milo, a hotly anticipated video game for Microsoft's Kinect controller. Perceptive and impressionable like a real 11-year-old, the virtual boy watches, listens and learns -- recognizing and responding to you. The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,AI,children,computers,design,gaming,psychology,technology  Meet Milo, the virtual boy
text.578: Jamil Abu-Wardeh jump-started the comedy scene in the Arab world by founding the Axis of Evil Middle East Comedy Tour, which brings standup comedians to laughing audiences all over the region. He's found that, by respecting the "three B's" (blue material, beliefs and "bolitics"), the Axis of Evil comics find plenty of cross-border laughs. The Creative Spark,War and Peace,comedy,entertainment,politics  The Axis of Evil Middle East Comedy Tour
text.579: A founding member of the Axis of Evil Comedy Tour, standup comic Maz Jobrani riffs on the challenges and conflicts of being Iranian-American -- "like, part of me thinks I should have a nuclear program; the other part thinks I can't be trusted ..." The Creative Spark,Whipsmart Comedy,War and Peace,Iran,Middle East,comedy,entertainment,politics  Did you hear the one about the Iranian-American?
text.580:
By now, we're used to letting Facebook and Twitter capture our social lives on the web -- building a "social layer" on top of the real world. In his talk, Seth Priebatsch looks at the next layer in progress: the "game layer," a pervasive net of behavior-steering game dynamics that will reshape education and commerce.
(Filmed at TEDxBoston.) The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,The Rise of Collaboration,TEDx,business,entertainment,entrepreneur,gaming,money,psychology  The game layer on top of the world
text.581: David McCandless turns complex data sets (like worldwide military spending, media buzz, Facebook status updates) into beautiful, simple diagrams that tease out unseen patterns and connections. Good design, he suggests, is the best way to navigate information glut -- and it may just change the way we see the world. The Creative Spark,Presentation Innovation,Design That Matters,complexity,computers,data,design,visualizations  The beauty of data visualization
text.582: Science columnist Lee Hotz describes a remarkable project at WAIS Divide, Antarctica, where a hardy team are drilling into ten-thousand-year-old ice to extract vital data on our changing climate. A Greener Future?,climate change,news,science  Inside an Antarctic time machine
text.583:
In the Gulf oil spill's aftermath, Lisa Margonelli says drilling moratoriums and executive ousters make for good theater, but distract from the issue at its heart: our unrestrained oil consumption. She shares her bold plan to wean America off of oil -- by confronting consumers with its real cost.
(Filmed at TEDxOilSpill.) A Greener Future?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,Ocean Wonders,TEDx,disaster relief,energy,environment,green,oil,sustainability  The political chemistry of oil
text.584: Statistician Nic Marks asks why we measure a nation's success by its productivity -- instead of by the happiness and well-being of its people. He introduces the Happy Planet Index, which tracks national well-being against resource use (because a happy life doesn't have to cost the earth). Which countries rank highest in the HPI? You might be surprised. What Makes Us Happy?,TEDBooks,big problems,culture,data,economics,global issues,happiness,statistics  The Happy Planet Index
text.585: Human growth has strained the Earth's resources, but as Johan Rockstrom reminds us, our advances also give us the science to recognize this and change behavior. His research has found nine "planetary boundaries" that can guide us in protecting our planet's many overlapping ecosystems. A Greener Future?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,agriculture,cities,climate change,environment,global issues  Let the environment guide our development
text.586: His Holiness the Karmapa talks about how he was discovered to be the reincarnation of a revered figure in Tibetan Buddhism. In telling his story, he urges us to work on not just technology and design, but the technology and design of the heart. He is translated onstage by Tyler Dewar. How the Mind Works,What Makes Us Happy?,brain,culture,happiness,religion,society  The technology of the heart
text.587: After hitting on a brilliant new life plan, our first instinct is to tell someone, but Derek Sivers says it's better to keep goals secret. He presents research stretching as far back as the 1920s to show why people who talk about their ambitions may be less likely to achieve them. The Creative Spark,How the Mind Works,Unconventional Explanations,How We Learn,goal-setting,motivation,personal growth,self,storytelling,success  Keep your goals to yourself
text.588: Rachel Sussman shows photographs of the world's oldest continuously living organisms -- from 2,000-year-old brain coral off Tobago's coast to an "underground forest" in South Africa that has lived since before the dawn of agriculture. Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,biodiversity,biology,environment,life,nature,photography,trees  The world's oldest living things
text.589: After 15 years in the British diplomatic corps, Carne Ross became a "freelance diplomat," running a bold nonprofit that gives small, developing and yet-unrecognized nations a voice in international relations. At the BIF-5 conference, he calls for a new kind of diplomacy that gives voice to small countries, that works with changing boundaries and that welcomes innovation. War and Peace,global issues,innovation,iraq,politics,state-building  An independent diplomat
text.590:
Arts administrator and live-theater fan Ben Cameron looks at the state of the live arts -- asking: How can the magic of live theater, live music, live dance compete with the always-on Internet? In his talk, he offers a bold look forward.
(Filmed at TEDxYYC.) The Creative Spark,Spectacular Performance,TEDx,arts,education,entertainment,performance  The true power of the performing arts
text.591: Rob Dunbar hunts for data on our climate from 12,000 years ago, finding clues inside ancient seabeds and corals and inside ice sheets. His work is vital in setting baselines for fixing our current climate -- and in tracking the rise of deadly ocean acidification. Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,mission blue,oceans,science,technology  Discovering ancient climates in oceans and ice
text.592: TED's Chris Anderson says the rise of web video is driving a worldwide phenomenon he calls Crowd Accelerated Innovation -- a self-fueling cycle of learning that could be as significant as the invention of print. But to tap into its power, organizations will need to embrace radical openness. And for TED, it means the dawn of a whole new chapter ... What's Next in Tech,The Rise of Collaboration,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,Technology, History and Destiny,How We Learn,Media With Meaning,business,education,global issues,innovation,online video,science,technology,web  How web video powers global innovation
text.593: In today's world, balancing school, work, kids and more, most of us can only hope for the recommended eight hours of sleep. Examining the science behind our body's internal clock, Jessa Gamble reveals the surprising and substantial program of rest we should be observing. Evolution's Genius,How the Mind Works,Unconventional Explanations,evolution,humanity,personal growth,science,self  Our natural sleep cycle is nothing like what we do now
text.594: After mapping humans' intricate social networks, Nicholas Christakis and colleague James Fowler began investigating how this information could better our lives. Now, he reveals his hot-off-the-press findings: These networks can be used to detect epidemics earlier than ever, from the spread of innovative ideas to risky behaviors to viruses (like H1N1).  Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,Medicine Without Borders,health,humanity,medicine,meme,science,society  How social networks predict epidemics
text.595: Caroline Phillips cranks out tunes on a seldom-heard folk instrument: the hurdy-gurdy, a.k.a. the wheel fiddle. A searching, Basque melody follows her fun lesson on its unique anatomy and 1,000-year history. Spectacular Performance,Tales of Invention,Live Music,culture,history,music,performance,singer,technology  Hurdy-gurdy for beginners
text.596: People often credit their ideas to individual "Eureka!" moments. But Steven Johnson shows how history tells a different story. His fascinating tour takes us from the "liquid networks" of London's coffee houses to Charles Darwin's long, slow hunch to today's high-velocity web. How the Mind Works,Tales of Invention,The Rise of Collaboration,Unconventional Explanations,collaboration,innovation,novel,science,technology  Where good ideas come from
text.597:
For the last eight years, pop singer Annie Lennox has devoted the majority of her time to her SING campaign, raising awareness and money to combat HIV/AIDS. She shares the experiences that have inspired her, from working with Nelson Mandela to meeting a little African girl in a desperate situation.
 Africa: The Next Chapter,Medicine Without Borders,AIDS,Africa,activism,health,personal growth  Why I am an HIV/AIDS activist
text.598:
Fabian Hemmert demos one future of the mobile phone -- a shape-shifting and weight-shifting handset that "displays" information nonvisually, offering a delightfully intuitive way to communicate.
(Filmed at TEDxBerlin.) What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,TEDx,communication,culture,design,interface design,telecom  The shape-shifting future of the mobile phone
text.599: At TED@Cannes, Gary Wolf gives a 5-min intro to an intriguing new pastime: using mobile apps and always-on gadgets to track and analyze your body, mood, diet, spending -- just about everything in daily life you can measure -- in gloriously geeky detail. What's Next in Tech,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,Medicine Without Borders,Numbers at Play,decision-making,design,health,medicine,psychology,statistics,technology  The quantified self
text.600: Sebastian Seung is mapping a massively ambitious new model of the brain that focuses on the connections between each neuron. He calls it our "connectome," and it's as individual as our genome -- and understanding it could open a new way to understand our brains and our minds. How the Mind Works,brain,mind,science,technology  I am my connectome
text.601: When Jungian analyst Inge Missmahl visited Afghanistan, she saw the inner wounds of war -- widespread despair, trauma and depression. And yet, in this county of 30 million people, there were only two dozen psychiatrists. Missmahl talks about her work helping to build the country's system of psychosocial counseling, promoting both individual and, perhaps, national healing. Rethinking Poverty,Unconventional Explanations,Medicine Without Borders,brain,depression,global issues,mental health,peace,politics,poverty,psychology,violence,war  Bringing peace to the minds of Afghanistan
text.602:
Thailand's "Mr. Condom," Mechai Viravaidya, walks us through the country's bold plan to raise its standard of living, starting in the 1970s. First step: population control. And that means a lot of frank, funny -- and very effective -- talk about condoms.
(Filmed at TEDxChange.) Rethinking Poverty,TEDx,culture,global issues,health,population,science  How Mr. Condom made Thailand a better place
text.603: Product designer Eben Bayer reveals his recipe for a new, fungus-based packaging material that protects fragile stuff like furniture, plasma screens -- and the environment. What's Next in Tech,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Tales of Invention,Design That Matters,Not Business as Usual,environment,green,nature,plastic,product design,technology  Are mushrooms the new plastic?
text.604: As the world faces recession, climate change, inequity and more, Tim Jackson delivers a piercing challenge to established economic principles, explaining how we might stop feeding the crises and start investing in our future. A Greener Future?,Rethinking Poverty,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,development,economics,green,poverty,sustainability  An economic reality check
text.605: Tuna are ocean athletes -- fast, far-ranging predators whose habits we're just beginning to understand. Marine biologist Barbara Block fits tuna with tracking tags (complete with transponders) that record unprecedented amounts of data about these gorgeous, threatened fish and the ocean habitats they move through. Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,mission blue,oceans,science,technology  Tagging tuna in the deep ocean
text.606:
Hans Rosling reframes 10 years of UN data with his spectacular visuals, lighting up an astonishing -- mostly unreported -- piece of front-page-worthy good news: We're winning the war against child mortality. Along the way, he debunks one flawed approach to stats that blots out such vital stories.
(Filmed at TEDxChange.) A Greener Future?,Rethinking Poverty,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,Medicine Without Borders,Africa,TEDx,data,development,health,inequality,statistics,third world  The good news of the decade?
text.607: Stacey Kramer offers a moving, personal, 3-minute parable that shows how an unwanted experience -- frightening, traumatic, costly -- can turn out to be a priceless gift. To Boldly Go ...,Is There a God?,What Makes Us Happy?,TED in 3 Minutes,TED Conference,cancer,medicine,personal growth,storytelling  The best gift I ever survived
text.608: Plants behave in some oddly intelligent ways: fighting predators, maximizing food opportunities ... But can we think of them as actually having a form of intelligence of their own? Italian botanist Stefano Mancuso presents intriguing evidence. Evolution's Genius,biology,collaboration,science  The roots of plant intelligence
text.609:
In her talk, Melinda Gates makes a provocative case for nonprofits taking a cue from corporations such as Coca-Cola, whose plugged-in, global network of marketers and distributors ensures that every remote village wants -- and can get -- a Coke. Why shouldn't this work for condoms, sanitation, vaccinations too?
(Filmed at TEDxChange.) Rethinking Poverty,Not Business as Usual,TEDx,business,development,global issues,philanthropy,sanitation  What nonprofits can learn from Coca-Cola
text.610:
"Haiti was not a natural disaster," says TED Fellow Peter Haas: "It was a disaster of engineering." As the country rebuilds after January's deadly quake, are bad old building practices creating another ticking time bomb? Haas's group, AIDG, is helping Haiti's builders learn modern building and engineering practices, to assemble a strong country brick by brick.
 The Creative Spark,Architectural Inspiration,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Fellows,architecture,business,disaster relief,global issues,natural disaster,technology  Haiti's disaster of engineering
text.611: Natalie Jeremijenko's unusual lab puts art to work, and addresses environmental woes by combining engineering know-how with public art and a team of volunteers. These real-life experiments include: Walking tadpoles, texting "fish," planting fire-hydrant gardens and more. The Creative Spark,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,The Rise of Collaboration,Design That Matters,art,arts,collaboration,design,engineering,environment,performance art,technology  The art of the eco-mindshift
text.612: What do you think of people in poverty? Maybe what Jessica Jackley once did: "they" need "our" help, in the form of a few coins in a jar. The co-founder of Kiva.org talks about how her attitude changed -- and how her work with microloans has brought new power to people who live on a few dollars a day. Rethinking Poverty,business,entrepreneur,global issues,poverty,social change,women in business  Poverty, money -- and love
text.613: Did you know you have functioning neurons in your intestines -- about a hundred million of them? Food scientist Heribert Watzke tells us about the "hidden brain" in our gut and the surprising things it makes us feel. Evolution's Genius,How the Mind Works,Unconventional Explanations,Food Matters,biology,food,science,technology  The brain in your gut
text.614: Artist Dianna Cohen shares some tough truths about plastic pollution in the ocean and in our lives -- and some thoughts on how to free ourselves from the plastic gyre. A Greener Future?,Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,consumerism,global issues,green,mission blue,oceans,plastic  Tough truths about plastic pollution
text.615:
In a series of witty punchlines, Patrick Chappatte makes a poignant case for the power of the humble cartoon. His projects in Lebanon, West Africa and Gaza show how, in the right hands, the pencil can illuminate serious issues and bring the most unlikely people together.

 The Creative Spark,Art Unusual,The Rise of Collaboration,Design That Matters,Whipsmart Comedy,Media With Meaning,art,media,news,politics,third world,war  The power of cartoons
text.616: Engineer RA Mashelkar shares three stories of ultra-low-cost design from India that use bottom-up rethinking, and some clever engineering, to bring expensive products (cars, prosthetics) into the realm of the possible for everyone. Tales of Invention,Rethinking Poverty,business,design,economics,industrial design,technology  Breakthrough designs for ultra-low-cost products
text.617: Historian and diplomat Joseph Nye gives us the 30,000-foot view of the shifts in power between China and the US, and the global implications as economic, political and "soft" power shifts and moves around the globe. The Rise of Collaboration,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Technology, History and Destiny,War and Peace,china,culture,economics,global issues,government,peace,politics,war  Global power shifts
text.618: Chef Barton Seaver presents a modern dilemma: Seafood is one of our healthier protein options, but overfishing is desperately harming our oceans. He suggests a simple way to keep fish on the dinner table that includes every mom's favorite adage  -- "Eat your vegetables!" A Greener Future?,Unconventional Explanations,Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,environment,fish,food,oceans,sustainability  Sustainable seafood? Let's get smart
text.619:
Shimon Steinberg looks at the difference between pests and bugs -- and makes the case for using good bugs to fight bad bugs, avoiding chemicals in our quest for perfect produce.
(Filmed at TEDxTelAviv.) Animals That Amaze,Evolution's Genius,What's Next in Tech,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,TEDx,agriculture,green,insects,nature,technology  Natural pest control ... using bugs!
text.620: Using animation, projections and her own moving shadow, Miwa Matreyek performs a gorgeous, meditative piece about inner and outer discovery. Take a quiet 10 minutes and dive in. With music from Anna Oxygen, Mirah, Caroline Lufkin and Mileece. The Creative Spark,art,arts,design,performance,technology  Glorious visions in animation and performance
text.621: We're bringing gameplay into more aspects of our lives, spending countless hours -- and real money -- exploring virtual worlds for imaginary treasures. Why? As Tom Chatfield shows, games are perfectly tuned to dole out rewards that engage the brain and keep us questing for more. The Creative Spark,culture,education,entertainment,gaming,technology  7 ways games reward the brain
text.622: David Bismark demos a new system for voting that contains a simple, verifiable way to prevent fraud and miscounting -- while keeping each person's vote secret. Tales of Invention,culture,democracy,design,global issues,government,politics,technology  E-voting without fraud
text.623: Aboard Mission Blue, scientist Greg Stone tells the story of how he helped the Republic of Kiribati create an enormous protected area in the middle of the Pacific -- protecting fish, sealife and the island nation itself. A Greener Future?,To Boldly Go ...,Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,global issues,mission blue,oceans,politics,science,submarine  Saving the ocean one island at a time
text.624: In the quest to map the brain, many scientists have attempted the incredibly daunting task of recording the activity of each neuron. Gero Miesenboeck works backward -- manipulating specific neurons to figure out exactly what they do, through a series of stunning experiments that reengineer the way fruit flies percieve light. How the Mind Works,Unconventional Explanations,biology,brain,neurology,science  Re-engineering the brain
text.625:
Musical innovator Andrew Bird winds together his trademark violin technique with xylophone, vocals and sophisticated electronic looping. Add in his uncanny ability to whistle anything, and he becomes a riveting one-man orchestra.  
 The Creative Spark,Spectacular Performance,Live Music,TED Conference,arts,entertainment,music,performance  A one-man orchestra of the imagination
text.626: Designer Emily Pilloton moved to rural Bertie County, in North Carolina, to engage in a bold experiment of design-led community transformation. She's teaching a design-build class called Studio H that engages high schoolers' minds and bodies while bringing smart design and new opportunities to the poorest county in the state. The Creative Spark,Rethinking Poverty,Women Reshaping the World,Listening to Teachers,design,education,poverty  Teaching design for change
text.627: Civil wars and ethnic conflicts have brought the world incredible suffering, but Stefan Wolff's figures show that, in the last 20 years, their number has steadily decreased. He extracts critical lessons from Northern Ireland, Liberia, Timor and more to show that leadership, diplomacy and institutional design are our three most effective weapons in waging peace. Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,War and Peace,Africa,iraq,peace,politics,third world,violence,war  The path to ending ethnic conflicts
text.628:
Aaron Huey's effort to photograph poverty in America led him to the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, where the struggle of the native Lakota people -- appalling, and largely ignored -- compelled him to refocus. Five years of work later, his haunting photos intertwine with a shocking history lesson in this bold, courageous talk.
(Filmed at TEDxDU.) Art Unusual,To Boldly Go ...,Rethinking Poverty,Master Storytellers,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,War and Peace,Media With Meaning,TEDx,culture,history,photography,poverty  America's native prisoners of war
text.629: FLA head Auret van Heerden talks about the next frontier of workers' rights -- globalized industries where no single national body can keep workers safe and protected. How can we keep our global supply chains honest? Van Heerden makes the business case for fair labor. Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,big problems,business,global issues,inequality,law,work  Making global labor fair
text.630: Ecologist Eric Berlow doesn't feel overwhelmed when faced with complex systems. He knows that more information can lead to a better, simpler solution. Illustrating the tips and tricks for breaking down big issues, he distills an overwhelming infographic on U.S. strategy in Afghanistan to a few elementary points. Design That Matters,Unconventional Explanations,Media With Meaning,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Fellows,complexity,design,science,simplicity  Simplifying complexity
text.631: From rockets to stock markets, many of humanity's most thrilling creations are powered by math. So why do kids lose interest in it? Conrad Wolfram says the part of math we teach -- calculation by hand -- isn't just tedious, it's mostly irrelevant to real mathematics and the real world. He presents his radical idea: teaching kids math through computer programming. What's Next in Tech,Design That Matters,Unconventional Explanations,How We Learn,Listening to Teachers,computers,education,math,technology  Teaching kids real math with computers
text.632: TED collaborates with animator Andrew Park to illustrate Denis Dutton's provocative theory on beauty -- that art, music and other beautiful things, far from being simply "in the eye of the beholder," are a core part of human nature with deep evolutionary origins.   The Creative Spark,Senses,TED Conference,arts,beauty,brain,culture,design,evolution,society  A Darwinian theory of beauty
text.633: Computer science professor Shimon Schocken is also an avid mountain biker. To share the life lessons he learned while riding, he began an outdoor program with Israel's juvenile inmates and was touched by both their intense difficulties and profound successes. Photographs by Raphael Rabinovitz. Inspired by Nature,Master Storytellers,Unconventional Explanations,TEDx,children,education,leadership,motivation,personal growth,sports,storytelling  What a bike ride can teach you
text.634: Join John Hardy on a tour of the Green School, his off-the-grid school in Bali that teaches kids how to build, garden, create (and get into college). The centerpiece of campus is the spiraling Heart of School, perhaps the world's largest freestanding bamboo building. A Greener Future?,Design That Matters,culture,design,education,green  My green school dream
text.635: Kristina Gjerde studies the law of the high seas -- the 64 percent of our ocean that isn't protected by any national law at all. Gorgeous photos show the hidden worlds that Gjerde and other lawyers are working to protect from trawling and trash-dumping, through smart policymaking and a healthy dose of PR. Animals That Amaze,Ocean Wonders,Mission Blue Voyage,global issues,law,mission blue,oceans,politics,science  Making law on the high seas
text.636:
In a lively talk, neuropsychologist Kim Gorgens makes the case for better protecting our brains against the risk of concussion -- with a compelling pitch for putting helmets on kids.
(Filmed at TEDxDU.) How the Mind Works,Medicine Without Borders,TEDx,brain,children,health,medicine  Protecting the brain against concussion
text.637: In war we often see only the frontline stories of soldiers and combat. AT TEDGlobal 2010, Zainab Salbi tells powerful "backline" stories of women who keep everyday life going during conflicts, and calls for women to have a place at the negotiating table once fighting is over.  War and Peace,Women Reshaping the World,drones,global issues,iraq,politics,war,women  Women, wartime and the dream of peace
text.638:
In this funny and insightful talk, builder Dan Phillips tours us through a dozen homes he's built in Texas using recycled and reclaimed materials in wildly creative ways. Brilliant, low-tech design details will refresh your own creative drive.
(Filmed at TEDxHouston.) The Creative Spark,TEDx,architecture,cities,creativity,design,green,technology  Creative houses from reclaimed stuff
text.639:
11-year-old Birke Baehr presents his take on a major source of our food -- far-away and less-than-picturesque industrial farms. Keeping farms out of sight promotes a rosy, unreal picture of big-box agriculture, he argues, as he outlines the case to green and localize food production.
(Filmed at TEDxNextGenerationAshevillen.) A Greener Future?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Design That Matters,TEDx,agriculture,business,environment,food,green,health,sustainability  What's wrong with our food system
text.640: Marcel Dicke makes an appetizing case for adding insects to everyone's diet. His message to squeamish chefs and foodies: delicacies like locusts and caterpillars compete with meat in flavor, nutrition and eco-friendliness. Animals That Amaze,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,To Boldly Go ...,Food Matters,agriculture,environment,food,health,insects  Why not eat insects?
text.641: No one knows exactly how many landmines still litter the world, but it's safe to safe: millions, waiting to kill and maim unsuspecting civilians. Clearing them is slow, expensive and dangerous. The founder of Apopo. Bart Weetjens, talks about his extraordinary project: training rats to sniff out land mines. He shows clips of his "hero rats" in action, and previews his work's next phase: teaching them to turn up tuberculosis in the lab. The Creative Spark,Animals That Amaze,Evolution's Genius,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,To Boldly Go ...,Africa: The Next Chapter,War and Peace,Africa,TEDx,animals,smell,technology,war  How I taught rats to sniff out land mines
text.642: If you've been in a restaurant kitchen, you've seen how much food, water and energy can be wasted there. Chef Arthur Potts-Dawson shares his very personal vision for drastically reducing restaurant, and supermarket, waste -- creating recycling, composting, sustainable engines for good (and good food). A Greener Future?,Food Matters,business,cities,culture,entertainment,food,global issues,sustainability  A vision for sustainable restaurants
text.643: Halla Tomasdottir managed to take her company Audur Capital through the eye of the financial storm in Iceland by applying 5 traditionally "feminine" values to financial services. At TEDWomen, she talks about these values and the importance of balance.  Not Business as Usual,Women Reshaping the World,Celebrating TEDWomen,business,feminism,politics,women,women in business  A feminine response to Iceland's financial crash
text.644: At TEDWomen, Tony Porter makes a call to men everywhere: Don't "act like a man." Telling powerful stories from his own life, he shows how this mentality, drummed into so many men and boys, can lead men to disrespect, mistreat and abuse women and each other. His solution: Break free of the "man box." Master Storytellers,Celebrating TEDWomen,bullying,culture,feminism,global issues,men,women,yesallwomen  A call to men
text.645: Kiran Bedi has a surprising resume. Before becoming Director General of the Indian Police Service, she managed one of the country's toughest prisons -- and used a new focus on prevention and education to turn it into a center of learning and meditation. She shares her thoughts on visionary leadership at TEDWomen. Women Reshaping the World,Celebrating TEDWomen,crime,culture,education,global issues,politics,social change  A police chief with a difference
text.646:
Hanna Rosin reviews startling new data that shows women actually surpassing men in several important measures, such as college graduation rates. Do these trends, both US-centric and global, signal the "end of men"? Probably not -- but they point toward an important societal shift worth deep discussion.
 Unconventional Explanations,Women Reshaping the World,Celebrating TEDWomen,culture,economics,education,feminism,global issues,women  New data on the rise of women
text.647:
Diana Laufenberg shares 3 surprising things she has learned about teaching -- including a key insight about learning from mistakes.

(Filmed at TEDxMidAtlantic.) How We Learn,Listening to Teachers,TEDx,children,culture,education  How to learn? From mistakes
text.648: Babble.com publishers Rufus Griscom and Alisa Volkman, in a lively tag-team, expose 4 facts that parents never, ever admit -- and why they should. Funny and honest, for parents and nonparents alike. What Makes Us Happy?,Celebrating TEDWomen,children,communication,culture,education,entertainment,sex,web  Let's talk parenting taboos
text.649: Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg looks at why a smaller percentage of women than men reach the top of their professions -- and offers 3 powerful pieces of advice to women aiming for the C-suite. Not Business as Usual,Celebrating TEDWomen,business,education,feminism,goal-setting,leadership,technology,women,women in business  Why we have too few women leaders
text.650:
The future of green is local -- and entrepreneurial. In her talk, Majora Carter brings us the stories of three people who are saving their own communities while saving the planet. Call it "hometown security."
(Filmed at TEDxMidWest.) Women Reshaping the World,TEDx,business,cities,community,economics,green  3 stories of local eco-entrepreneurship
text.651: In an intimate talk, Barry Schwartz dives into the question "How do we do the right thing?" With help from collaborator Kenneth Sharpe, he shares stories that illustrate the difference between following the rules and truly choosing wisely.  How the Mind Works,Master Storytellers,culture,global issues,happiness,philosophy,self  Using our practical wisdom
text.652:
Lesley Hazleton sat down one day to read the Koran. And what she found -- as a non-Muslim, a self-identified "tourist" in the Islamic holy book -- wasn't what she expected. With serious scholarship and warm humor, Hazleton shares the grace, flexibility and mystery she found, in this myth-debunking talk.
(Filmed at TEDxRainier.)
 Is There a God?,Master Storytellers,TEDx,culture,global issues,journalism,religion  On reading the Koran
text.653:
Musician and researcher Charles Limb wondered how the brain works during musical improvisation -- so he put jazz musicians and rappers in an fMRI to find out. What he and his team found has deep implications for our understanding of creativity of all kinds.
(Filmed at TEDxMidAtlantic.) The Creative Spark,How the Mind Works,Spectacular Performance,TEDx,brain,creativity,entertainment,music,science,technology  Your brain on improv
text.654: Working with a team of physicists, Dr. Deborah Rhodes developed a new tool for tumor detection that's 3 times as effective as traditional mammograms for women with dense breast tissue. The life-saving implications are stunning. So why haven't we heard of it? Rhodes shares the story behind the tool's creation, and the web of politics and economics that keep it from mainstream use. What's Next in Tech,Design That Matters,Celebrating TEDWomen,business,cancer,medicine,science,technology  A test that finds 3x more breast tumors, and why it's not available to you
text.655:
Neil Pasricha's blog 1000 Awesome Things savors life's simple pleasures, from free refills to clean sheets. In this heartfelt talk, he reveals the 3 secrets (all starting with A) to leading a life that's truly awesome.
(Filmed at TEDxToronto.) Master Storytellers,What Makes Us Happy?,TEDx,book,happiness,life,love,personal growth,psychology,writing  The 3 A's of awesome
text.656: Nobel Peace laureate Jody Williams brings tough love to the dream of world peace, with her razor-sharp take on what "peace" really means, and a set of profound stories that zero in on the creative struggle -- and sacrifice -- of those who work for it. War and Peace,Women Reshaping the World,Celebrating TEDWomen,activism,global issues,humanity,nuclear weapons,peace  A realistic vision for world peace
text.657: Technology is evolving us, says Amber Case, as we become a screen-staring, button-clicking new version of homo sapiens. We now rely on "external brains" (cell phones and computers) to communicate, remember, even live out secondary lives. But will these machines ultimately connect or conquer us? Case offers surprising insight into our cyborg selves. Evolution's Genius,Celebrating TEDWomen,anthropology,computers,culture,cyborg,future,technology  We are all cyborgs now
text.658: There's an angry divisive tension in the air that threatens to make modern politics impossible. Elizabeth Lesser explores the two sides of human nature within us (call them "the mystic" and "the warrior”) that can be harnessed to elevate the way we treat each other. She shares a simple way to begin real dialogue -- by going to lunch with someone who doesn't agree with you, and asking them three questions to find out what's really in their hearts. Celebrating TEDWomen,communication,global issues,politics  Take "the Other" to lunch
text.659: In her talk, Ali Carr-Chellman pinpoints three reasons boys are tuning out of school in droves, and lays out her bold plan to re-engage them: bringing their culture into the classroom, with new rules that let boys be boys, and video games that teach as well as entertain. Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Design That Matters,How We Learn,Media With Meaning,Women Reshaping the World,TEDx,bullying,children,education,gaming,psychology,technology,violence  Gaming to re-engage boys in learning
text.660: Days before this talk, journalist Naomi Klein was on a boat in the Gulf of Mexico, looking at the catastrophic results of BP's risky pursuit of oil. Our societies have become addicted to extreme risk in finding new energy, new financial instruments and more ... and too often, we're left to clean up a mess afterward. Klein's question: What's the backup plan? Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,Celebrating TEDWomen,activism,business,culture,economics,science,social change  Addicted to risk
text.661: You'll never sing again, said her doctor. But in a story from the very edge of medical possibility, operatic soprano Charity Tillemann-Dick tells a double story of survival -- of her body, from a double lung transplant, and of her spirit, fueled by an unwavering will to sing. A powerful story from TEDMED 2010. The Creative Spark,Medicine Without Borders,arts,health care,medicine,music,science,technology  Singing after a double lung transplant
text.662:
Van Jones lays out a case against plastic pollution from the perspective of social justice. Because plastic trash, he shows us, hits poor people and poor countries "first and worst," with consequences we all share no matter where we live and what we earn. In this powerful talk, he offers a few powerful ideas to help us reclaim our throwaway planet.
(Filmed at TEDxGPGP.)
 A Greener Future?,TEDx,business,communication,global issues,green,inequality,plastic,poverty,science  The economic injustice of plastic
text.663:
Today medical scans produce thousands of images and terabytes of data for a single patient in mere seconds, but how do doctors parse this information and determine what's useful? In this talk, scientific visualization expert Anders Ynnerman shows us sophisticated new tools -- like virtual autopsies -- for analyzing this myriad data, and a glimpse at some sci-fi-sounding medical technologies in development. This talk contains some graphic medical imagery.
(Filmed at TEDxGöteborg.) What's Next in Tech,Medicine Without Borders,TEDx,data,health,medicine,science,technology,visualizations  Visualizing the medical data explosion
text.664: Your medical chart: it's hard to access, impossible to read -- and full of information that could make you healthier if you just knew how to use it. At TEDMED, Thomas Goetz looks at medical data, making a bold call to redesign it and get more insight from it. Design That Matters,Medicine Without Borders,business,design,health,medicine,science,technology  It's time to redesign medical data
text.665: New Yorker cartoonist Liza Donnelly shares a portfolio of her wise and funny cartoons about modern life -- and talks about how humor can empower women to change the rules. Art Unusual,Whipsmart Comedy,Celebrating TEDWomen,art,comedy,culture,feminism,humor,media,peace,women  Drawing on humor for change
text.666: Diagnosed with cancer, Bruce Feiler worried first about his young family. So -- as he shares in this funny, rambling and ultimately thoughtful talk -- he asked his closest friends to become a "council of dads," bringing their own lifetimes of wisdom to advise his twin daughters as they grow. Master Storytellers,cancer,community,culture,storytelling  The council of dads
text.667: Architect Kate Orff sees the oyster as an agent of urban change. Bundled into beds and sunk into city rivers, oysters slurp up pollution and make legendarily dirty waters clean -- thus driving even more innovation in "oyster-tecture." Orff shares her vision for an urban landscape that links nature and humanity for mutual benefit. Architectural Inspiration,Ocean Wonders,Food Matters,Celebrating TEDWomen,architecture,biology,cities,design  Reviving New York's rivers -- with oysters!
text.668: America was built by makers -- curious, enthusiastic amateur inventors whose tinkering habit sparked whole new industries. At TED@MotorCity, MAKE magazine publisher Dale Dougherty says we're all makers at heart, and shows cool new tools to tinker with, like Arduinos, affordable 3D printers, even DIY satellites. The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,cities,collaboration,computers,curiosity,design,drones,hack,innovation,media,technology  We are makers
text.669: Media and advertising companies still use the same old demographics to understand audiences, but they're becoming increasingly harder to track online, says media researcher Johanna Blakley. As social media outgrows traditional media, and women users outnumber men, Blakley explains what changes are in store for the future of media. Not Business as Usual,Media With Meaning,Women Reshaping the World,Celebrating TEDWomen,advertising,culture,entertainment,media,social media  Social media and the end of gender
text.670: Christopher McDougall explores the mysteries of the human desire to run. How did running help early humans survive -- and what urges from our ancient ancestors spur us on today? McDougall tells the story of the marathoner with a heart of gold, the unlikely ultra-runner, and the hidden tribe in Mexico that runs to live. What Makes Us Happy?,TEDx,entertainment,health,journalism,science,sports  Are we born to run?
text.671: Poet Suheir Hammad performs two spine-tingling spoken-word pieces: "What I Will" and "break (clustered)" -- meditations on war and peace, on women and power. Wait for the astonishing line: "Do not fear what has blown up. If you must, fear the unexploded." The Creative Spark,War and Peace,Celebrating TEDWomen,arts,culture,global issues,poetry,war,women  Poems of war, peace, women, power
text.672: Cynthia Breazeal wonders: Why can we use robots on Mars, but not in our living rooms? The key, she says, is in training robots to interact with people. Now she dreams up and builds robots that teach, learn -- and play. Watch for amazing demo footage of a new interactive game for kids. What's Next in Tech,What Makes Us Happy?,Celebrating TEDWomen,AI,body language,business,communication,design,entertainment,robots,technology  The rise of personal robots
text.673: They've been called the "saints of Somalia." Doctor Hawa Abdi and her daughter Deqo Mohamed discuss their medical clinic in Somalia, where -- in the face of civil war and open oppression of women -- they've built a hospital, a school and a community of peace. Medicine Without Borders,Women Reshaping the World,Celebrating TEDWomen,community,global issues,health,medicine,politics,science,women  Mother and daughter doctor-heroes
text.674:
In this engaging talk, world champion whistler Geert Chatrou performs the whimsical "Eleonora" by A. Honhoff, and his own "Fête de la Belle." In a fascinating interlude, he talks about what brought him to the craft.
(Filmed at TEDxRotterdam .) Spectacular Performance,Live Music,TEDx,entertainment,live music,music,performance  A whistleblower you haven't heard
text.675: The term "compassion" -- typically reserved for the saintly or the sappy -- has fallen out of touch with reality. At a special TEDPrize@UN, journalist Krista Tippett deconstructs the meaning of compassion through several moving stories, and proposes a new, more attainable definition for the word. The Charter for Compassion,charter for compassion,compassion,faith,religion,science  Reconnecting with compassion
text.676:
Patricia Kuhl shares astonishing findings about how babies learn one language over another -- by listening to the humans around them and "taking statistics" on the sounds they need to know. Clever lab experiments (and brain scans) show how 6-month-old babies use sophisticated reasoning to understand their world.
(Filmed at TEDxRainier.) How the Mind Works,Words About Words,TEDx,brain,children,language,science,technology  The linguistic genius of babies
text.677: We each want to live a life of purpose, but where to start? In this luminous, wide-ranging talk, Jacqueline Novogratz introduces us to people she's met in her work in "patient capital" -- people who have immersed themselves in a cause, a community, a passion for justice. These human stories carry powerful moments of inspiration. Rethinking Poverty,Master Storytellers,Celebrating TEDWomen,culture,economics,global issues,investment,women in business  Inspiring a life of immersion
text.678: Lisa Gansky, author of "The Mesh," talks about a future of business that's about sharing all kinds of stuff, either via smart and tech-enabled rental or, more boldly, peer-to-peer. Examples across industries -- from music to cars -- show how close we are to this meshy future. The Power of Cities,Not Business as Usual,business,technology  The future of business is the "mesh"
text.679: Former US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright talks bluntly about politics and diplomacy, making the case that women's issues deserve a place at the center of foreign policy. Far from being a "soft" issue, she says, women's issues are often the very hardest ones, dealing directly with life and death. A frank and funny Q&A with Pat Mitchell from the Paley Center. Master Storytellers,Women Reshaping the World,Celebrating TEDWomen,Foreign Policy,business,iraq  On being a woman and a diplomat
text.680:
Maxillofacial surgeon Iain Hutchison works with people whose faces have been severely disfigured. By pushing to improve surgical techniques, he helps to improve their lives; and by commissioning their portraits, he celebrates their humanity. NOTE: This talk contains images of disfigured and badly injured faces that may be disturbing -- and Hutchison provides thoughtful answers as to why a disfigured face can shock us so deeply. Squeamish? Hide your screen from 12:10 - 13:19, but do keep listening. Portraits shown in this talk come from Mark Gilbert.
 Medicine Without Borders,arts,body language,community,culture,design,medical research  Saving faces
text.681: Danny Hills makes a case for the next frontier of cancer research: proteomics, the study of proteins in the body. As Hillis explains it, genomics shows us a list of the ingredients of the body -- while proteomics shows us what those ingredients produce. Understanding what's going on in your body at the protein level may lead to a new understanding of how cancer happens.  Tales of Invention,Medicine Without Borders,cancer,genetics,medical research  Understanding cancer through proteomics
text.682: The three Ahn sisters (cellist Maria, pianist Lucia, violinist Angella) breathe new life into the piano trio with their passionate musicmaking. At TEDWomen, they start with the bright and poppy "Skylife," by David Balakrishnan, then play a gorgeous, slinky version of "Oblivion," by Astor Piazzolla. The Creative Spark,Live Music,Celebrating TEDWomen,arts,entertainment,live music  A modern take on piano, violin, cello
text.683: As a democratic revolution led by tech-empowered young people sweeps the Arab world, Wadah Khanfar, the head of Al Jazeera, shares a profoundly optimistic view of what's happening in Egypt, Tunisia, Libya and beyond -- at this powerful moment when people realized they could step out of their houses and ask for change. Africa: The Next Chapter,Media With Meaning,Egypt,Middle East,TED Conference,global issues,iraq,media,politics,protests,technology  A historic moment in the Arab world
text.684: Wael Ghonim is the Google executive who helped jumpstart Egypt's democratic revolution ... with a Facebook page memorializing a victim of the regime's violence. Speaking at TEDxCairo, he tells the inside story of the past two months, when everyday Egyptians showed that "the power of the people is stronger than the people in power." War and Peace,Egypt,TED Conference,democracy,global issues,politics,protests,social change  Inside the Egyptian revolution
text.685: America's school systems are funded by the 50 states. In this fiery talk, Bill Gates says that state budgets are riddled with accounting tricks that disguise the true cost of health care and pensions and weighted with worsening deficits -- with the financing of education at the losing end. Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,TED Conference,aging,education,money,politics,youth  How state budgets are breaking US schools
text.686: Surgeon Anthony Atala demonstrates an early-stage experiment that could someday solve the organ-donor problem: a 3D printer that uses living cells to output a transplantable kidney. Using similar technology, Dr. Atala's young patient Luke Massella received an engineered bladder 10 years ago; we meet him onstage. Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,Medicine Without Borders,Surgery,TED Conference,health care,invention,medical research,prosthetics  Printing a human kidney
text.687: Blogger Courtney Martin examines the perennially loaded word "feminism" in this personal and heartfelt talk. She talks through the three essential paradoxes of her generation's quest to define the term for themselves. Women Reshaping the World,Celebrating TEDWomen,culture,feminism,history,identity,women,writing  This isn't her mother's feminism
text.688: Salman Khan talks about how and why he created the remarkable Khan Academy, a carefully structured series of educational videos offering complete curricula in math and, now, other subjects.
