He shows the power of interactive exercises, and calls for teachers to consider flipping the traditional classroom script -- give students video lectures to watch at home, and do "homework" in the classroom with the teacher available to help. How We Learn,TED Conference,culture,education,global issues,online video  Let's use video to reinvent education
text.689: As web companies strive to tailor their services (including news and search results) to our personal tastes, there's a dangerous unintended consequence: We get trapped in a "filter bubble" and don't get exposed to information that could challenge or broaden our worldview. Eli Pariser argues powerfully that this will ultimately prove to be bad for us and bad for democracy.  What's Next in Tech,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,TED Conference,culture,global issues,journalism,politics,technology  Beware online "filter bubbles"
text.690:
With streams and rivers drying up because of over-usage, Rob Harmon has implemented an ingenious market mechanism to bring back the water. Farmers and beer companies find their fates intertwined in the intriguing century-old tale of Prickly Pear Creek.
(Filmed at TEDxRainier.) Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,TEDx,business,environment,global issues,innovation,nature,sustainability,water  How the market can keep streams flowing
text.691: Columnist David Brooks unpacks new insights into human nature from the cognitive sciences -- insights with massive implications for economics and politics as well as our own self-knowledge. In a talk full of humor, he shows how you can't hope to understand humans as separate individuals making choices based on their conscious awareness.  How the Mind Works,TED Conference,brain,culture,motivation,society  The social animal
text.692: We think of space as a silent place. But physicist Janna Levin says the universe has a soundtrack -- a sonic composition that records some of the most dramatic events in outer space. (Black holes, for instance, bang on spacetime like a drum.) An accessible and mind-expanding soundwalk through the universe. To Boldly Go ...,Peering into Space,TED Conference,dark matter,science,universe  The sound the universe makes
text.693:
Lighting architect Rogier van der Heide offers a beautiful new way to look at the world -- by paying attention to light (and to darkness). Examples from classic buildings illustrate a deeply thought-out vision of the play of light around us.
(Filmed at TEDxAmsterdam.) The Creative Spark,Architectural Inspiration,TEDx,architecture,design  Why light needs darkness
text.694: "If I should have a daughter, instead of Mom, she's gonna call me Point B ... " began spoken word poet Sarah Kay, in a talk that inspired two standing ovations at TED2011. She tells the story of her metamorphosis -- from a wide-eyed teenager soaking in verse at New York's Bowery Poetry Club to a teacher connecting kids with the power of self-expression through Project V.O.I.C.E. -- and gives two breathtaking performances of "B" and "Hiroshima." The Creative Spark,Spectacular Performance,Master Storytellers,Words About Words,TED Conference,entertainment,performance,poetry,storytelling  If I should have a daughter ...
text.695: With never-before-seen video, primatologist Isabel Behncke Izquierdo (a TED Fellow) shows how bonobo ape society learns from constantly playing -- solo, with friends, even as a prelude to sex. Indeed, play appears to be the bonobos' key to problem-solving and avoiding conflict. If it works for our close cousins, why not for us? Animals That Amaze,Evolution's Genius,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Conference,TED Fellows,animals,culture,play,science  Evolution's gift of play, from bonobo apes to humans
text.696: Eythor Bender of Berkeley Bionics brings onstage two amazing exoskeletons, HULC and eLEGS -- robotic add-ons that could one day allow a human to carry 200 pounds without tiring, or allow a wheelchair user to stand and walk. It's a powerful onstage demo, with implications for human potential of all kinds. What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Design That Matters,TED Conference,design,disability,exoskeleton,science,technology  Human exoskeletons -- for war and healing
text.697:
"The human voice: mysterious, spontaneous, primal." With these words, soprano Claron McFadden invites us to explore the mysteries of breathing and singing, as she performs the challenging "Aria," by John Cage.
(Filmed at TEDxAmsterdam.) The Creative Spark,Spectacular Performance,TEDx,arts,creativity,entertainment,music  Singing the primal mystery
text.698: When first discovered in 2010, the Stuxnet computer worm posed a baffling puzzle. Beyond its sophistication loomed a more troubling mystery: its purpose. Ralph Langner and team helped crack the code that revealed this digital warhead's final target. In a fascinating look inside cyber-forensics, he explains how -- and makes a bold (and, it turns out, correct) guess at its shocking origins. What's Next in Tech,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,War and Peace,Numbers at Play,Iran,TED Conference,computers,government,nuclear energy,politics,science,technology,war  Cracking Stuxnet, a 21st-century cyber weapon
text.699: "Puppets always have to try to be alive," says Adrian Kohler of the Handspring Puppet Company, a gloriously ambitious troupe of human and wooden actors. Beginning with the tale of a hyena's subtle paw, puppeteers Kohler and Basil Jones build to the story of their latest astonishment: the wonderfully life-like Joey, the War Horse, who trots (and gallops) convincingly onto the TED stage. The Creative Spark,Animals That Amaze,TED Conference,animals,arts,design,entertainment,theater  The genius puppetry behind War Horse
text.700: Sebastian Thrun helped build Google's amazing driverless car, powered by a very personal quest to save lives and reduce traffic accidents. Jawdropping video shows the DARPA Challenge-winning car motoring through busy city traffic with no one behind the wheel, and dramatic test drive footage from TED2011 demonstrates how fast the thing can really go. What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Design That Matters,TED Conference,business,robots,science,technology,transportation  Google's driverless car
text.701: In a moving and madly viral video last year, composer Eric Whitacre led a virtual choir of singers from around the world. He talks through the creative challenges of making music powered by YouTube, and unveils the first 2 minutes of his new work, "Sleep," with a video choir of 2,052. The full piece premiered a few weeks later (yes, on YouTube!). The Creative Spark,TED Conference,arts,conducting,entertainment,music,online video  A virtual choir 2,000 voices strong
text.702: Four-star general Stanley McChrystal shares what he learned about leadership over his decades in the military. How can you build a sense of shared purpose among people of many ages and skill sets? By listening and learning -- and addressing the possibility of failure. War and Peace,TED Conference,culture,global issues,iraq,leadership,peace,war  Listen, learn ... then lead
text.703: Google's "Jolly Good Fellow," Chade-Meng Tan, talks about how the company practices compassion in its everyday business -- and its bold side projects. Not Business as Usual,The Charter for Compassion,business,charter for compassion,culture  Everyday compassion at Google
text.704: With humor and persistence, filmmaker Morgan Spurlock dives into the hidden but influential world of brand marketing, on his quest to make a completely sponsored film about sponsorship. (And yes, onstage naming rights for this talk were sponsored too. By whom and for how much? He'll tell you.) The Creative Spark,Not Business as Usual,Brand,TED Conference,business,consumerism,film,humor  The greatest TED Talk ever sold
text.705: The nerve disease ALS left graffiti artist TEMPT paralyzed from head to toe, forced to communicate blink by blink. In a remarkable talk at TEDActive, entrepreneur Mick Ebeling shares how he and a team of collaborators built an open-source invention that gave the artist -- and gives others in his circumstance -- the means to make art again. The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,The Rise of Collaboration,Design That Matters,creativity,design,disease,invention,open-source,technology  The invention that unlocked a locked-in artist
text.706: Activist Caroline Casey tells the story of her extraordinary life, starting with a revelation (no spoilers). In a talk that challenges perceptions, Casey asks us all to move beyond the limits we may think we have. Master Storytellers,Not Business as Usual,Women Reshaping the World,Celebrating TEDWomen,activism,business,culture  Looking past limits
text.707: Backed by stunning illustrations, David Christian narrates a complete history of the universe, from the Big Bang to the Internet, in a riveting 18 minutes. This is "Big History": an enlightening, wide-angle look at complexity, life and humanity, set against our slim share of the cosmic timeline. Presentation Innovation,The Rise of Collaboration,Peering into Space,Technology, History and Destiny,Unconventional Explanations,Listening to Teachers,Internet,TED Conference,big bang,cosmos,education,history,humanity,universe,visualizations  The history of our world in 18 minutes
text.708:
Local politics -- schools, zoning, council elections -- hit us where we live. So why don't more of us actually get involved? Is it apathy? Dave Meslin says no. He identifies 7 barriers that keep us from taking part in our communities, even when we truly care.
(Filmed at TEDxToronto.) The Power of Cities,The Rise of Collaboration,Design That Matters,Media With Meaning,TEDx,collaboration,community,culture,education,global issues,politics  The antidote to apathy
text.709:
Sarah Kaminsky tells the extraordinary story of her father Adolfo and his activity during World War II -- using his ingenuity and talent for forgery to save lives.
(Filmed at TEDxParis.) Master Storytellers,War and Peace,TEDx,book,culture,entertainment,global issues,history,storytelling,war  My father the forger
text.710: When film critic Roger Ebert lost his lower jaw to cancer, he lost the ability to eat and speak. But he did not lose his voice. In a moving talk from TED2011, Ebert and his wife, Chaz, with friends Dean Ornish and John Hunter, come together to tell his remarkable story. The Creative Spark,Master Storytellers,Words About Words,TED Conference,arts,community,culture,speech  Remaking my voice
text.711: Pioneering surgeon Susan Lim performed the first liver transplant in Asia. But a moral concern with transplants (where do donor livers come from ...) led her to look further, and to ask: Could we be transplanting cells, not whole organs? At the INK Conference, she talks through her new research, discovering healing cells in some surprising places. Medicine Without Borders,business,technology  Transplant cells, not organs
text.712:
By leading the Americans in his audience step by step through the thought process, sociologist Sam Richards sets an extraordinary challenge: can they understand -- not approve of, but understand -- the motivations of an Iraqi insurgent? And by extension, can anyone truly understand and empathize with another? 
(Filmed at TEDxPSU.) How the Mind Works,To Boldly Go ...,Master Storytellers,War and Peace,TEDx,culture,empathy,global issues,iraq,politics,society,sociology,war  A radical experiment in empathy
text.713: John Hunter puts all the problems of the world on a 4'x5' plywood board -- and lets his 4th-graders solve them. At TED2011, he explains how his World Peace Game engages schoolkids, and why the complex lessons it teaches -- spontaneous, and always surprising -- go further than classroom lectures can. The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,The Rise of Collaboration,Rethinking Poverty,Master Storytellers,Design That Matters,How We Learn,Listening to Teachers,TED Conference,design,education,gaming,global issues,government,peace,politics,war  Teaching with the World Peace Game
text.714: All over the planet, giant telescopes and detectors are looking (and listening) for clues to the workings of the universe. At the INK Conference, science writer Anil Ananthaswamy tours us around these amazing installations, taking us to some of the most remote and silent places on Earth. To Boldly Go ...,Peering into Space,exploration,journalism,science,technology,universe  What it takes to do extreme astrophysics
text.715: Medical ethicist Harvey Fineberg shows us three paths forward for the ever-evolving human species: to stop evolving completely, to evolve naturally -- or to control the next steps of human evolution, using genetic modification, to make ourselves smarter, faster, better. Neo-evolution is within our grasp. What will we do with it? Evolution's Genius,Technology, History and Destiny,Medicine Without Borders,TED Conference,evolution,medicine,philosophy,science,technology  Are we ready for neo-evolution?
text.716: The feeling of security and the reality of security don't always match, says computer-security expert Bruce Schneier. In his talk, he explains why we spend billions addressing news story risks, like the "security theater" now playing at your local airport, while neglecting more probable risks -- and how we can break this pattern. Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,TEDx,culture,global issues,security,technology,terrorism  The security mirage
text.717: Inspired by an abalone shell, Angela Belcher programs viruses to make elegant nanoscale structures that humans can use. Selecting for high-performing genes through directed evolution, she's produced viruses that can construct powerful new batteries, clean hydrogen fuels and record-breaking solar cells. In her talk, she shows us how it's done. Evolution's Genius,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,DNA,TEDx,alternative energy,biology,evolution,genetics,nature,virus  Using nature to grow batteries
text.718: Software developer Mike Matas demos the first full-length interactive book for the iPad -- with clever, swipeable video and graphics and some very cool data visualizations to play with. The book is "Our Choice," Al Gore's sequel to "An Inconvenient Truth."  The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Words About Words,TED Conference,demo,design,entertainment,software,technology  A next-generation digital book
text.719: At the INK Conference, Arvind Gupta shares simple yet stunning plans for turning trash into seriously entertaining, well-designed toys that kids can build themselves -- while learning basic principles of science and design.  The Creative Spark,Design That Matters,How We Learn,design,education,play,science,technology,toy  Turning trash into toys for learning
text.720: Phyllis Rodriguez and Aicha el-Wafi have a powerful friendship born of unthinkable loss. Rodriguez' son was killed in the World Trade Center attacks on September 11, 2001; el-Wafi's son Zacarias Moussaoui was convicted of a role in those attacks and is serving a life sentence. In hoping to find peace, these two moms have come to understand and respect one another. The Rise of Collaboration,Women Reshaping the World,culture,global issues,parenting,politics,terrorism  The mothers who found forgiveness, friendship
text.721: With his team at SENSEable City Lab, MIT's Carlo Ratti makes cool things by sensing the data we create. He pulls from passive data sets -- like the calls we make, the garbage we throw away -- to create surprising visualizations of city life. And he and his team create dazzling interactive environments from moving water and flying light, powered by simple gestures caught through sensors. The Power of Cities,Architectural Inspiration,TED Conference,cities,design,entertainment,technology  Architecture that senses and responds
text.722: Designer Suzanne Lee shares her experiments in growing a kombucha-based material that can be used like fabric or vegetable leather to make clothing. The process is fascinating, the results are beautiful (though there's still one minor drawback ...) and the potential is simply stunning. Tales of Invention,Design That Matters,Women Reshaping the World,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Conference,TED Fellows,bacteria,biology,biotech,creativity,design,fashion,materials,technology  Grow your own clothes
text.723: Cosmologist Sean Carroll attacks -- in an entertaining and thought-provoking tour through the nature of time and the universe -- a deceptively simple question: Why does time exist at all? The potential answers point to a surprising view of the nature of the universe, and our place in it. Peering into Space,Unconventional Explanations,String theory,TEDx,astronomy,cosmos,philosophy,physics,science,time,universe  Distant time and the hint of a multiverse
text.724: Pollination: it's vital to life on Earth, but largely unseen by the human eye. Filmmaker Louie Schwartzberg shows us the intricate world of pollen and pollinators with gorgeous high-speed images from his film "Wings of Life," inspired by the vanishing of one of nature's primary pollinators, the honeybee. Animals That Amaze,Evolution's Genius,Inspired by Nature,Hidden Gems,TED Conference,beauty,bees,evolution,film,garden,insects,life,nature  The hidden beauty of pollination
text.725:
Diving under the Antarctic ice to get close to the much-feared leopard seal, photographer Paul Nicklen found an extraordinary new friend. Share his hilarious, passionate stories of the polar wonderlands, illustrated by glorious images of the animals who live on and under the ice.
 Animals That Amaze,TED Conference,animals,biodiversity,creativity,culture,design,entertainment,photography,storytelling  Tales of ice-bound wonderlands
text.726: Fiorenzo Omenetto shares 20+ astonishing new uses for silk, one of nature's most elegant materials -- in transmitting light, improving sustainability, adding strength and making medical leaps and bounds. On stage, he shows a few intriguing items made of the versatile stuff. The Creative Spark,Animals That Amaze,What's Next in Tech,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Tales of Invention,Medicine Without Borders,TED Conference,biology,biomimicry,design,green,invention,life,medicine,science,technology  Silk, the ancient material of the future
text.727: Ron Gutman reviews a raft of studies about smiling, and reveals some surprising results. Did you know your smile can be a predictor of how long you'll live -- and that a simple smile has a measurable effect on your overall well-being? Prepare to flex a few facial muscles as you learn more about this evolutionarily contagious behavior. How the Mind Works,What Makes Us Happy?,TED Conference,body language,culture,happiness,science,society  The hidden power of smiling
text.728: Imagine being able to see artwork in the greatest museums around the world without leaving your chair. Driven by his passion for art, Amit Sood tells the story of how he developed Art Project to let people do just that. The Creative Spark,TED Conference,art,arts,design,technology  Building a museum of museums on the web
text.729:
What's it like to be pals with a genius? Onstage, physicist Leonard Susskind spins a few stories about his friendship with the legendary Richard Feynman, discussing his unconventional approach to problems both serious and ... less so.
(Filmed at TEDxCaltech.) Tales of Invention,Master Storytellers,TEDx,culture,history,physics,science,storytelling  My friend Richard Feynman
text.730: A future more beautiful? Architect Thomas Heatherwick shows five recent projects featuring ingenious bio-inspired designs. Some are remakes of the ordinary: a bus, a bridge, a power station ... And one is an extraordinary pavilion, the Seed Cathedral, a celebration of growth and light. The Creative Spark,Inspired by Nature,Tales of Invention,TED Conference,architecture,arts,creativity,design  Building the Seed Cathedral
text.731: We think of pain as a symptom, but there are cases where the nervous system develops feedback loops and pain becomes a terrifying disease in itself. Starting with the story of a girl whose sprained wrist turned into a nightmare, Elliot Krane talks about the complex mystery of chronic pain, and reviews the facts we're just learning about how it works and how to treat it. How the Mind Works,Medicine Without Borders,Senses,TED Conference,brain,health,health care,pain,science  The mystery of chronic pain
text.732: In the deep, dark ocean, many sea creatures make their own light for hunting, mating and self-defense. Bioluminescence expert Edith Widder was one of the first to film this glimmering world. At TED2011, she brings some of her glowing friends onstage, and shows more astonishing footage of glowing undersea life. Animals That Amaze,To Boldly Go ...,Ocean Wonders,TED Conference,biology,deextinction,exploration,oceans,photography,science  The weird, wonderful world of bioluminescence
text.733: Terry Moore found out he'd been tying his shoes the wrong way his whole life. In the spirit of TED, he takes the stage to share a better way. (Historical note: This was the very first 3-minute audience talk given from the TED stage, in 2005.) TED in 3 Minutes,Hidden Gems,TED Conference,culture,demo,entertainment  How to tie your shoes
text.734: Artist Aaron Koblin takes vast amounts of data -- and at times vast numbers of people -- and weaves them into stunning visualizations. From elegant lines tracing airline flights to landscapes of cell phone data, from a Johnny Cash video assembled from crowd-sourced drawings to the "Wilderness Downtown" video that customizes for the user, his works brilliantly explore how modern technology can make us more human. Art Unusual,Media With Meaning,TED Conference,arts,collaboration,data,design,technology,visualizations  Visualizing ourselves ... with crowd-sourced data
text.735: Journalist Mustafa Akyol talks about the way that some local cultural practices (such as the seclusion of women) have become linked, in the popular mind, to the articles of faith of Islam. Has the world's general idea of the Islamic faith focused too much on tradition, and not enough on core beliefs? Is There a God?,Egypt,Islam,TEDx,culture,democracy,religion  Faith versus tradition in Islam
text.736: It's a master class in collaboration as violinist Robert Gupta and cellist Joshua Roman perform Halvorsen's "Passacaglia" for violin and viola. Roman takes the viola part on his Stradivarius cello. It's powerful to watch the two musicians connect moment to moment (and recover from a mid-performance hiccup). The two are both TED Fellows, and their deep connection powers this sparkling duet.  Live Music,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Conference,TED Fellows,collaboration,creativity,entertainment,live music  On violin and cello, "Passacaglia"
text.737: Using robotics, laser rangefinders, GPS and smart feedback tools, Dennis Hong is building a car for drivers who are blind. It's not a "self-driving" car, he's careful to note, but a car in which a non-sighted driver can determine speed, proximity and route -- and drive independently. What's Next in Tech,Senses,TED Conference,design,sight,technology,transportation  Making a car for blind drivers
text.738: Using simple, delightful illustrations, designer Stefan Sagmeister shares his latest thinking on happiness -- both the conscious and unconscious kind. His seven rules for life and design happiness can (with some customizations) apply to everyone seeking more joy. Tales of Invention,What Makes Us Happy?,arts,design,film,happiness,motivation  7 rules for making more happiness
text.739: Physicists are used to the idea that subatomic particles behave according to the bizarre rules of quantum mechanics, completely different to human-scale objects. In a breakthrough experiment, Aaron O'Connell has blurred that distinction by creating an object that is visible to the unaided eye, but provably in two places at the same time. In this talk he suggests an intriguing way of thinking about the result. What's Next in Tech,Inspired by Nature,TED Conference,philosophy,physics,science  Making sense of a visible quantum object
text.740: Designer Jessi Arrington packed nothing for TEDActive but 7 pairs of undies, buying the rest of her clothes in thrift stores around LA. It's a meditation on conscious consumption -- wrapped in a rainbow of color and creativity. The Creative Spark,Art Unusual,consumerism,creativity,culture,design,fashion  Wearing nothing new
text.741:
Damon Horowitz reviews the enormous new powers that technology gives us: to know more -- and more about each other -- than ever before. Drawing the audience into a philosophical discussion, Horowitz invites us to pay new attention to the basic philosophy -- the ethical principles -- behind the burst of invention remaking our world. Where's the moral operating system that allows us to make sense of it?
(Filmed at TEDxSiliconValley.) Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,TEDx,culture,philosophy,technology  We need a "moral operating system"
text.742: Renowned paleontologist Jack Horner has spent his career trying to reconstruct a dinosaur. He's found fossils with extraordinarily well-preserved blood vessels and soft tissues, but never intact DNA. So, in a new approach, he's taking living descendants of the dinosaur (chickens) and genetically engineering them to reactivate ancestral traits — including teeth, tails, and even hands — to make a "Chickenosaurus". Animals That Amaze,Evolution's Genius,dinosaurs,genetics,paleontology,science  Building a dinosaur from a chicken
text.743: Janet Echelman found her true voice as an artist when her paints went missing -- which forced her to look to an unorthodox new art material. Now she makes billowing, flowing, building-sized sculpture with a surprisingly geeky edge. A transporting 10 minutes of pure creativity. The Creative Spark,Art Unusual,TED Conference,art,arts,cities,culture,data,design,technology,visualizations  Taking imagination seriously
text.744: Back in 2009, Paul Romer unveiled the idea for a "charter city" -- a new kind of city with rules that favor democracy and trade. This year, at TED2011, he tells the story of how such a city might just happen in Honduras ... with a little help from his TEDTalk. The Power of Cities,TED Conference,business,cities,culture,design,global issues,politics  The world's first charter city?
text.745:
Alice Dreger works with people at the edge of anatomy, such as conjoined twins and intersexed people. In her observation, it's often a fuzzy line between male and female, among other anatomical distinctions. Which brings up a huge question: Why do we let our anatomy determine our fate?
(Filmed at TEDxNorthwesternU.) Unconventional Explanations,TEDx,culture,gender,politics  Is anatomy destiny?
text.746: Even when our lives appear fine from the outside, locked within can be a world of quiet suffering, leading some to the decision to end their life. At TEDYou, JD Schramm asks us to break the silence surrounding suicide and suicide attempts, and to create much-needed resources to help people who reclaim their life after escaping death. Resources: http://t.co/wsNrY9C Master Storytellers,communication,culture,depression,mental health,storytelling,suicide  Break the silence for suicide attempt survivors
text.747:
Daniel Kraft offers a fast-paced look at the next few years of innovations in medicine, powered by new tools, tests and apps that bring diagnostic information right to the patient's bedside.
(Filmed at TEDxMaastricht.) Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,Medicine Without Borders,TEDx,design,health care,science,technology  Medicine's future? There's an app for that
text.748: How do you stage an international art show with work from 100 different artists? If you're Shea Hembrey, you invent all of the artists and artwork yourself -- from large-scale outdoor installations to tiny paintings drawn with a single-haired brush. Watch this funny, mind-bending talk to see the explosion of creativity and diversity of skills a single artist is capable of. The Creative Spark,Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,What Makes Us Happy?,TED Conference,art,arts,creativity,design,storytelling  How I became 100 artists
text.749:
Steve Keil fights the "serious meme" that has infected his home of Bulgaria -- and calls for a return to play to revitalize the economy, education and society. A sparkling talk with a universal message for people everywhere who are reinventing their workplaces, schools, lives.
(Filmed at TEDxBG.) What Makes Us Happy?,Europe,TEDx,business,culture,economics,play,social change  A manifesto for play, for Bulgaria and beyond
text.750: Photographer Camille Seaman shoots icebergs, showing the world the complex beauty of these massive, ancient chunks of ice. Dive in to her photo slideshow, "The Last Iceberg." Inspired by Nature,Art Unusual,TED Conference,TED Fellows,art,arts,glacier,global issues,photography  Haunting photos of polar ice
text.751: Musician and inventor Onyx Ashanti demonstrates "beatjazz" -- his music created with two handheld controllers, an iPhone and a mouthpiece, and played with the entire body. At TED's Full Spectrum Auditions, after locking in his beats and loops, he plays a 3-minute song that shares his vision for the future of music. Tales of Invention,Art Unusual,Live Music,design,entertainment,live music,music,technology  This is beatjazz
text.752: Cellist Maya Beiser plays a gorgeous eight-part modern etude with seven copies of herself, and segues into a meditative music/video hybrid -- using tech to create endless possibilities for transformative sound. Music is Steve Reich's "Cello Counterpoint," with video from Bill Morrison, then David Lang's "World to Come," with video by Irit Batsry. The Creative Spark,Spectacular Performance,Live Music,TED Conference,design,entertainment,live music,music,technology  A cello with many voices
text.753: Bill Ford is a car guy -- his great-grandfather was Henry Ford, and he grew up inside the massive Ford Motor Co. So when he worries about cars' impact on the environment, and about our growing global gridlock problem, it's worth a listen. His vision for the future of mobility includes "smart roads," even smarter public transport and going green like never before. Tales of Invention,Technology, History and Destiny,TED Conference,cars,cities,design,mobility,technology  A future beyond traffic gridlock
text.754: Daniel Tammet has linguistic, numerical and visual synesthesia -- meaning that his perception of words, numbers and colors are woven together into a new way of perceiving and understanding the world. The author of "Born on a Blue Day," Tammet shares his art and his passion for languages in this glimpse into his beautiful mind. How the Mind Works,Art Unusual,Words About Words,Numbers at Play,TED Conference,arts,brain,culture  Different ways of knowing
text.755: In this 3-minute talk, cartoonist and educator Jok Church tells a moving story of the teacher who cared for him when no one else did -- and how he returned the favor.  TED in 3 Minutes,Hidden Gems,TED Conference,culture,education,love,storytelling  A circle of caring
text.756: Artist-technologist Honor Harger listens to the weird and wonderful noises of stars and planets and pulsars. In her work, she tracks the radio waves emitted by ancient celestial objects and turns them into sound, including "the oldest song you will ever hear," the sound of cosmic rays left over from the Big Bang. Peering into Space,art,arts,astronomy,design,entertainment,physics,sound,technology  A history of the universe in sound
text.757: At TED's Full Spectrum Auditions, comedian Joshua Walters, who's bipolar, walks the line between mental illness and mental "skillness." In this funny, thought-provoking talk, he asks: What's the right balance between medicating craziness away and riding the manic edge of creativity and drive? The Creative Spark,Whipsmart Comedy,brain,depression,entertainment,mental health,performance  On being just crazy enough
text.758: In this passionate talk that's already caused a sensation in Mexico, Emiliano Salinas, son of former president Carlos Salinas de Gortari, confronts the current climate of violence in Mexico -- or rather, how Mexican society responds to it. He calls on ordinary citizens to move from denial and fear to peaceful, community-based action. (Delivered in Spanish with English subtitles.) War and Peace,TEDx,community,crime,global issues,peace,social change,terrorism,violence  A civil response to violence
text.759: Rajesh Rao is fascinated by "the mother of all crossword puzzles": how to decipher the 4000-year-old Indus script. He's enlisting modern computation to try to read this lost language, the key to understanding this ancient civilization. Tales of Invention,Technology, History and Destiny,TED Conference,computers,history,language,science  A Rosetta Stone for a lost language
text.760: When Dave deBronkart learned he had a rare and terminal cancer, he turned to a group of fellow patients online -- and found the medical treatment that saved his life. Now he calls on all patients to talk with one another, know their own health data, and make health care better one e-Patient at a time. Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,Medicine Without Borders,TEDx,collaboration,culture,data,health care,science,technology  Meet e-Patient Dave
text.761: New York was planning to tear down the High Line, an abandoned elevated railroad in Manhattan, when Robert Hammond and a few friends suggested: Why not make it a park? He shares how it happened in this tale of local cultural activism. The Power of Cities,Art Unusual,TED Conference,activism,arts,cities,culture  Building a park in the sky
text.762: Is there something you've always meant to do, wanted to do, but just ... haven't? Matt Cutts suggests: Try it for 30 days. This short, lighthearted talk offers a neat way to think about setting and achieving goals. How We Learn,TED Conference,culture,success  Try something new for 30 days
text.763: Cookbook author (and geek) Nathan Myhrvold talks about his magisterial work, "Modernist Cuisine" -- and shares the secret of its cool photographic illustrations, which show cross-sections of food in the very act of being cooked. The Creative Spark,Unconventional Explanations,Food Matters,TED Conference,arts,creativity,design,entertainment,food,photography,technology  Cooking as never seen before
text.764: In this visually dazzling talk, Jonathan Drori shows the extraordinary ways flowering plants -- over a quarter million species -- have evolved to attract insects to spread their pollen: growing 'landing-strips' to guide the insects in, shining in ultraviolet, building elaborate traps, and even mimicking other insects in heat. Evolution's Genius,bees,biology,botany,environment,insects,life,science,sex  The beautiful tricks of flowers
text.765: After a catastrophic car accident that left him in a coma, Simon Lewis found ways to recover -- physically and mentally -- beyond all expectations. At the INK Conference he tells how this remarkable story led him to concern over all threats to consciousness, and how to overcome them. How the Mind Works,How We Learn,consciousness,medicine,technology  Don't take consciousness for granted
text.766: In this powerful talk from TEDGlobal, Rebecca MacKinnon describes the expanding struggle for freedom and control in cyberspace, and asks: How do we design the next phase of the Internet with accountability and freedom at its core, rather than control? She believes the internet is headed for a "Magna Carta" moment when citizens around the world demand that their governments protect free speech and their right to connection. Media With Meaning,culture,politics,protests,social media  Let's take back the Internet!
text.767: Economics writer Tim Harford studies complex systems -- and finds a surprising link among the successful ones: they were built through trial and error. In this sparkling talk from TEDGlobal 2011, he asks us to embrace our randomness and start making better mistakes. Tales of Invention,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,business,creativity,culture,society  Trial, error and the God complex
text.768: As political turmoil in Yemen continues, the editor of the Yemen Times, Nadia Al-Sakkaf, talks at TEDGlobal with host Pat Mitchell. Al-Sakkaf's independent, English-language paper is vital for sharing news -- and for sharing a new vision of Yemen and of that country's women as equal partners in work and change. War and Peace,Media With Meaning,Women Reshaping the World,communication,global issues,journalism,politics,war,women  See Yemen through my eyes
text.769: It's been 25 years since the first PC virus (Brain A) hit the net, and what was once an annoyance has become a sophisticated tool for crime and espionage. Computer security expert Mikko Hyppönen tells us how we can stop these new viruses from threatening the internet as we know it. What's Next in Tech,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Internet,TEDx,computers,crime,global issues,technology,virus  Fighting viruses, defending the net
text.770: We live in a world run by algorithms, computer programs that make decisions or solve problems for us. In this riveting, funny talk, Kevin Slavin shows how modern algorithms determine stock prices, espionage tactics, even the movies you watch. But, he asks: If we depend on complex algorithms to manage our daily decisions -- when do we start to lose control? What's Next in Tech,To Boldly Go ...,complexity,computers,social change,technology  How algorithms shape our world
text.771: Plenty of robots can fly -- but none can fly like a real bird. That is, until Markus Fischer and his team at Festo built SmartBird, a large, lightweight robot, modeled on a seagull, that flies by flapping its wings. A soaring demo fresh from TEDGlobal 2011. Animals That Amaze,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,animals,biomechanics,biomimicry,design,robots,technology  A robot that flies like a bird
text.772: Physicist Geoffrey West has found that simple, mathematical laws govern the properties of cities -- that wealth, crime rate, walking speed and many other aspects of a city can be deduced from a single number: the city's population. In this mind-bending talk from TEDGlobal he shows how it works and how similar laws hold for organisms and corporations. The Power of Cities,Inspired by Nature,Unconventional Explanations,biology,business,cities,complexity,math,science  The surprising math of cities and corporations
text.773: Why do we like an original painting better than a forgery? Psychologist Paul Bloom argues that human beings are essentialists -- that our beliefs about the history of an object change how we experience it, not simply as an illusion, but as a deep feature of what pleasure (and pain) is. Evolution's Genius,How the Mind Works,What Makes Us Happy?,happiness,philosophy,psychology,science  The origins of pleasure
text.774: Josette Sheeran, the head of the UN's World Food Program, talks about why, in a world with enough food for everyone, people still go hungry, still die of starvation, still use food as a weapon of war. Her vision: "Food is one issue that cannot be solved person by person. We have to stand together." Rethinking Poverty,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,War and Peace,Women Reshaping the World,Food Matters,culture,economics,food,global issues,peace,politics,war  Ending hunger now
text.775: In our louder and louder world, says sound expert Julian Treasure, "We are losing our listening." In this short, fascinating talk, Treasure shares five ways to re-tune your ears for conscious listening -- to other people and the world around you. How the Mind Works,arts,culture,sound  5 ways to listen better
text.776: Many of us have a social media presence -- a virtual personality made up of status updates, tweets and connections, stored in the cloud. Adam Ostrow asks a big question: What happens to that personality after you've died? Could it ... live on? What's Next in Tech,Technology, History and Destiny,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,consciousness,culture,self,social change,social media,technology  After your final status update
text.777: What if every light bulb in the world could also transmit data? At TEDGlobal, Harald Haas demonstrates, for the first time, a device that could do exactly that. By flickering the light from a single LED, a change too quick for the human eye to detect, he can transmit far more data than a cellular tower -- and do it in a way that's more efficient, secure and widespread. The Creative Spark,What's Next in Tech,Not Business as Usual,Internet,cities,invention,technology  Wireless data from every light bulb
text.778: Biologist Mark Pagel shares an intriguing theory about why humans evolved our complex system of language. He suggests that language is a piece of "social technology" that allowed early human tribes to access a powerful new tool: cooperation. Evolution's Genius,Words About Words,biology,communication,culture,evolution,language,science  How language transformed humanity
text.779: Should we keep the outdoors out of hospitals? Ecologist and TED Fellow Jessica Green has found that mechanical ventilation does get rid of many types of microbes, but the wrong kinds: the ones left in the hospital are much more likely to be pathogens. A Greener Future?,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Design That Matters,Women Reshaping the World,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Fellows,health,microbiology,science  Are we filtering the wrong microbes?
text.780: Poet, writer, activist Eve Ensler lived in her head. In this powerful talk from TEDWomen, she talks about her lifelong disconnection from her body -- and how two shocking events helped her to connect with the reality, the physicality of being human. What Makes Us Happy?,Women Reshaping the World,Celebrating TEDWomen,activism,arts,brain,cancer,culture,poetry  Suddenly, my body
text.781: Psychologist Philip Zimbardo asks, "Why are boys struggling?" He shares some stats (lower graduation rates, greater worries about intimacy and relationships) and suggests a few reasons -- and challenges the TED community to think about solutions. Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Unconventional Explanations,TED Conference,culture,education,feminism,gaming,gender,sex  The demise of guys?
text.782: How can cities help save the future? Alex Steffen shows some cool neighborhood-based green projects that expand our access to things we want and need -- while reducing the time we spend in cars. Architectural Inspiration,A Greener Future?,Design That Matters,architecture,cities,collaboration,design,energy,environment,green,technology  The shareable future of cities
text.783:
A personal story, a collective triumph: Dyan deNapoli tells the story of the world's largest volunteer animal rescue, which saved more than 40,000 penguins after an oil spill off the coast of South Africa. How does a job this big get done? Penguin by penguin by penguin ...
(Filmed at TEDxBoston.) Animals That Amaze,Ocean Wonders,TEDx,animals,birds,collaboration,global issues,oceans,science  The great penguin rescue
text.784: Here's a crazy idea: Persuade the world to try living in peace for just one day, every September 21. In this energetic, honest talk, Jeremy Gilley tells the story of how this crazy idea became real -- real enough to help millions of kids in war-torn regions.  War and Peace,activism,collaboration,global issues,peace,war  One day of peace
text.785: How do we find planets -- even habitable planets -- around other stars? By looking for tiny dimming as a planet passes in front of its sun, TED Fellow Lucianne Walkowicz and the Kepler mission have found some 1,200 potential new planetary systems. With new techniques, they may even find ones with the right conditions for life. Peering into Space,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Fellows,exploration,science,technology,universe  Finding planets around other stars
text.786: Using three iPods like magical props, Marco Tempest spins a clever, surprisingly heartfelt meditation on truth and lies, art and emotion.  Spectacular Performance,Master Storytellers,What Makes Us Happy?,art,arts,design,entertainment,illusion,magic,music,technology  The magic of truth and lies (and iPods)
text.787: In this short talk, psychologist Dan Ariely tells two personal stories that explore scientific conflict of interest: How the pursuit of knowledge and insight can be affected, consciously or not, by shortsighted personal goals. When we're thinking about the big questions, he reminds us, let's be aware of our all-too-human brains. How the Mind Works,Master Storytellers,Medicine Without Borders,TED Conference,cognitive science,economics,medical research,science,technology  Beware conflicts of interest
text.788: Sharing the results of a massive, worldwide study, geneticist Svante Pääbo shows the DNA proof that early humans mated with Neanderthals after we moved out of Africa. (Yes, many of us have Neanderthal DNA.) He also shows how a tiny bone from a baby finger was enough to identify a whole new humanoid species. Evolution's Genius,DNA,biology,evolution,science  DNA clues to our inner neanderthal
text.789: In 2003, the Palestinian village of Budrus mounted a 10-month-long nonviolent protest to stop a barrier being built across their olive groves. Did you hear about it? Didn't think so. Brazilian filmmaker Julia Bacha asks why we only pay attention to violence in the Israel-Palestine conflict -- and not to the nonviolent leaders who may one day bring peace. War and Peace,Women Reshaping the World,arts,communication,compassion,entertainment,film,peace,violence,war  Pay attention to nonviolence
text.790: Buddhist roshi Joan Halifax works with people at the last stage of life (in hospice and on death row). She shares what she's learned about compassion in the face of death and dying, and a deep insight into the nature of empathy. Master Storytellers,Women Reshaping the World,Celebrating TEDWomen,Buddhism,compassion,culture,death,global issues  Compassion and the true meaning of empathy
text.791: Before life existed on Earth, there was just matter, inorganic dead "stuff." How improbable is it that life arose? And -- could it use a different type of chemistry? Using an elegant definition of life (anything that can evolve), chemist Lee Cronin is exploring this question by attempting to create a fully inorganic cell using a "Lego kit" of inorganic molecules -- no carbon -- that can assemble, replicate and compete. Evolution's Genius,To Boldly Go ...,biology,life,nanoscale,science  Making matter come alive
text.792: Artist Raghava KK demos his new children's book for iPad with a fun feature: when you shake it, the story -- and your perspective -- changes. In this charming short talk, he invites all of us to shake up our perspective a little bit. Art Unusual,Master Storytellers,arts,book,creativity,design,entertainment,technology  Shake up your story
text.793: Economist Yasheng Huang compares China to India, and asks how China's authoritarian rule contributed to its astonishing economic growth -- leading to a big question: Is democracy actually holding India back? Huang's answer may surprise you. Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,Asia,culture,democracy,economics,global issues,politics  Does democracy stifle economic growth?
text.794: Despite multibillion-dollar investments in cybersecurity, one of its root problems has been largely ignored: who are the people who write malicious code? Underworld investigator Misha Glenny profiles several convicted coders from around the world and reaches a startling conclusion. Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Not Business as Usual,Technology, History and Destiny,Internet,computers,crime,global issues,technology  Hire the hackers!
text.795: Artist Kate Hartman uses wearable electronics to explore how we communicate, with ourselves and with the world. In this quirky and thought-provoking talk, she shows the "Talk to Yourself Hat", the "Inflatable Heart", the "Glacier Embracing Suit", and other unexpected devices. The Creative Spark,Inspired by Nature,A Greener Future?,Art Unusual,TED Conference,art,communication,culture,glacier  The art of wearable communication
text.796:
In this accessible talk from TEDxBoston, Richard Resnick shows how cheap and fast genome sequencing is about to turn health care (and insurance, and politics) upside down.

(Filmed at TEDxBoston.) Medicine Without Borders,DNA,TEDx,biotech,health care,science,technology  Welcome to the genomic revolution
text.797: Over the past few centuries, Western cultures have been very good at creating general prosperity for themselves. Historian Niall Ferguson asks: Why the West, and less so the rest? He suggests half a dozen big ideas from Western culture -- call them the 6 killer apps -- that promote wealth, stability and innovation. And in this new century, he says, these apps are all shareable. Rethinking Poverty,Technology, History and Destiny,business,culture,economics,global issues  The 6 killer apps of prosperity
text.798:
Have you played with Google Labs' Ngram Viewer? It's an addicting tool that lets you search for words and ideas in a database of 5 million books from across centuries. Erez Lieberman Aiden and Jean-Baptiste Michel show us how it works, and a few of the surprising things we can learn from 500 billion words. 
(Filmed at TEDxBoston.) Words About Words,Google,TEDx,data,design,library,technology,visualizations,writing  What we learned from 5 million books
text.799: HIV is a serious problem in the DR Congo, and aid agencies have flooded the country with free and cheap condoms. But few people are using them. Why? "Reformed marketer" Amy Lockwood offers a surprising answer that upends a traditional model of philanthropy. (Some NSFW images.) Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,Africa,business,global issues,marketing,philanthropy  Selling condoms in the Congo
text.800: What is killing the Tasmanian devil? A virulent cancer is infecting them by the thousands  -- and unlike most cancers, it's contagious. Researcher Elizabeth Murchison tells us how she's fighting to save the Taz, and what she's learning about all cancers from this unusual strain. Contains disturbing images of facial cancer. Medicine Without Borders,animals,biology,cancer,science  Fighting a contagious cancer
text.801: Modern medicine is in danger of losing a powerful, old-fashioned tool: human touch. Physician and writer Abraham Verghese describes our strange new world where patients are merely data points, and calls for a return to the traditional one-on-one physical exam. Medicine Without Borders,communication,culture,health,health care,medicine,science  A doctor's touch
text.802: Some kids learn by listening; others learn by doing. Geoff Mulgan gives a short introduction to the Studio School, a new kind of school in the UK where small teams of kids learn by working on projects that are, as Mulgan puts it, "for real."  How We Learn,Listening to Teachers,creativity,culture,design,education,work  A short intro to the Studio School
text.803: Every day there are news reports of new health advice, but how can you know if they're right? Doctor and epidemiologist Ben Goldacre shows us, at high speed, the ways evidence can be distorted, from the blindingly obvious nutrition claims to the very subtle tricks of the pharmaceutical industry. Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Medicine Without Borders,Food Matters,data,health care,illness,illusion,medicine,science  Battling bad science
text.804: Can opera be ever-so-slightly sexy? The glorious soprano Danielle de Niese shows how, singing the flirty "Meine Lippen, sie küssen so heiss." Which, translated, means, as you might guess: "I kiss so hot." From Giuditta by Frans Lehár; accompanist: Ingrid Surgenor. Live Music,arts,creativity,entertainment,sex  A flirtatious aria
text.805: Yang Lan, a journalist and entrepreneur who's been called "the Oprah of China," offers insight into the next generation of young Chinese citizens -- urban, connected (via microblogs) and alert to injustice. Women Reshaping the World,Asia,china,economics,global issues,media,politics  The generation that's remaking China
text.806: How do we search for alien life if it's nothing like the life that we know? Christoph Adami shows how he uses his research into artificial life -- self-replicating computer programs -- to find a signature, a 'biomarker,' that is free of our preconceptions of what life is. Evolution's Genius,Inspired by Nature,Unconventional Explanations,TEDx,bacteria,biology,evolution,life,science  Finding life we can't imagine
text.807: Writer and designer Graham Hill asks: Can having less stuff, in less room, lead to more happiness? He makes the case for taking up less space, and lays out three rules for editing your life. What Makes Us Happy?,TED Conference,consumerism,culture,design,happiness,media,simplicity  Less stuff, more happiness
text.808: Conductor Charles Hazlewood talks about the role of trust in musical leadership -- then shows how it works, as he conducts the Scottish Ensemble onstage. He also shares clips from two musical projects: the opera "U-Carmen eKhayelitsha" and the ParaOrchestra. Spectacular Performance,Live Music,arts,collaboration,conducting,culture,entertainment,music  Trusting the ensemble
text.809: "Babies and young children are like the R&D division of the human species," says psychologist Alison Gopnik. Her research explores the sophisticated intelligence-gathering and decision-making that babies are really doing when they play. Unconventional Explanations,How We Learn,brain,children,culture,education,psychology  What do babies think?
text.810: A story, a work of art, a face, a designed object -- how do we tell that something is beautiful?  And why does it matter so much to us? Designer Richard Seymour explores our response to beauty and the surprising power of objects that exhibit it. Design That Matters,What Makes Us Happy?,Senses,arts,beauty,design,happiness  How beauty feels
text.811: Imagine it's late 1990, and you've just met a nice young man named Tim Berners-Lee, who starts telling you about his proposed system called the World Wide Web. Ian Ritchie was there. And ... he didn't buy it. A short story about information, connectivity and learning from mistakes. Master Storytellers,Not Business as Usual,Technology, History and Destiny,business,history,technology,web  The day I turned down Tim Berners-Lee
text.812: On any given day we're lied to from 10 to 200 times, and the clues to detect those lie can be subtle and counter-intuitive. Pamela Meyer, author of Liespotting, shows the manners and "hotspots" used by those trained to recognize deception -- and she argues honesty is a value worth preserving. How the Mind Works,Hidden Gems,culture,psychology,science,society  How to spot a liar
text.813: Here's a powerful provocation from artist Jae Rhim Lee. Can we commit our bodies to a cleaner, greener Earth, even after death? Naturally -- using a special burial suit seeded with pollution-gobbling mushrooms. Yes, this just might be the strangest TEDTalk you'll ever see ... A Greener Future?,Technology, History and Destiny,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Fellows,arts,death,design,green,invention  My mushroom burial suit
text.814: In Rajasthan, India, an extraordinary school teaches rural women and men -- many of them illiterate -- to become solar engineers, artisans, dentists and doctors in their own villages. It's called the Barefoot College, and its founder, Bunker Roy, explains how it works. The Creative Spark,Master Storytellers,Not Business as Usual,How We Learn,culture,development,education,global issues,invention,women  Learning from a barefoot movement
text.815: What would happen if we could generate power from our windowpanes? In this moving talk, entrepreneur Justin Hall-Tipping shows the materials that could make that possible, and how questioning our notion of 'normal' can lead to extraordinary breakthroughs. A Greener Future?,Tales of Invention,The Rise of Collaboration,energy,entrepreneur,environment,science,technology  Freeing energy from the grid
text.816:
More and more, nations are waging attacks with cyber weapons -- silent strikes on another country's computer systems that leave behind no trace. (Think of the Stuxnet worm.) Guy-Philippe Goldstein shows how cyberattacks can leap between the digital and physical worlds to prompt armed conflict -- and how we might avert this global security hazard.
(Filmed at TEDxParis.) Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,War and Peace,computers,global issues,politics,security,technology,terrorism,war  How cyberattacks threaten real-world peace
text.817: Physiatrist and engineer Todd Kuiken is building a prosthetic arm that connects with the human nervous system -- improving motion, control and even feeling. Onstage, patient Amanda Kitts helps demonstrate this next-gen robotic arm. Design That Matters,Medicine Without Borders,Senses,design,engineering,invention,medicine,prosthetics,science,technology  A prosthetic arm that "feels"
text.818: Artist Nathalie Miebach takes weather data from massive storms and turns it into complex sculptures that embody the forces of nature and time. These sculptures then become musical scores for a string quartet to play. Inspired by Nature,Art Unusual,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Fellows,art,arts,data,visualizations,weather  Art made of storms
text.819: We feel instinctively that societies with huge income gaps are somehow going wrong. Richard Wilkinson charts the hard data on economic inequality, and shows what gets worse when rich and poor are too far apart: real effects on health, lifespan, even such basic values as trust. Rethinking Poverty,Not Business as Usual,Unconventional Explanations,Medicine Without Borders,culture,data,global issues,inequality,money,social change,visualizations  How economic inequality harms societies
text.820: Master storyteller Malcolm Gladwell tells the tale of the Norden bombsight, a groundbreaking piece of World War II technology with a deeply unexpected result. Tales of Invention,Master Storytellers,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,drones,invention,war  The strange tale of the Norden bombsight
text.821:
How does cancer know it's cancer? At Jay Bradner's lab, they found a molecule that might hold the answer, JQ1 -- and instead of patenting JQ1, they published their findings and mailed samples to 40 other labs to work on. An inspiring look at the open-source future of medical research.
(Filmed at TEDxBoston.) Tales of Invention,Not Business as Usual,Medicine Without Borders,TEDx,business,cancer,medical research,open-source,science  Open-source cancer research
text.822: After he ended up on a watch list by accident, Hasan Elahi was advised by his local FBI agents to let them know when he was traveling. He did that and more ... much more. Presentation Innovation,Art Unusual,art,arts,data,security,war,web  FBI, here I am!
text.823: What drives our desire to behave morally? Neuroeconomist Paul Zak shows why he believes oxytocin (he calls it "the moral molecule") is responsible for trust, empathy and other feelings that help build a stable society. Evolution's Genius,What Makes Us Happy?,Medicine Without Borders,brain,culture,medicine,morality,science  Trust, morality -- and oxytocin?
text.824: Neuroscientist Daniel Wolpert starts from a surprising premise: the brain evolved, not to think or feel, but to control movement. In this entertaining, data-rich talk he gives us a glimpse into how the brain creates the grace and agility of human motion. Evolution's Genius,How the Mind Works,biology,brain,evolution,neurology,science  The real reason for brains
text.825: In his lab, Martin Hanczyc makes "protocells," experimental blobs of chemicals that behave like living cells. His work demonstrates how life might have first occurred on Earth ... and perhaps elsewhere too. Evolution's Genius,biology,chemistry,life,science  The line between life and not-life
text.826: Artist and TED Fellow Aparna Rao re-imagines the familiar in surprising, often humorous ways. With her collaborator Soren Pors, Rao creates high-tech art installations -- a typewriter that sends emails, a camera that tracks you through the room only to make you invisible on screen -- that put a playful spin on ordinary objects and interactions. The Creative Spark,Art Unusual,Talks from TED Fellows,TED Fellows,art,creativity,humor,technology  High-tech art (with a sense of humor)
text.827: Ancient monuments give us clues to astonishing past civilizations -- but they're under threat from pollution, war, neglect. Ben Kacyra, who invented a groundbreaking 3D scanning system, is using his invention to scan and preserve the world's heritage in archival detail. (Watch to the end for a little demo.) Technology, History and Destiny,history,invention,technology  Ancient wonders captured in 3D
text.828: How can we begin to understand the way the brain works? The same way we begin to understand a city: by making a map. In this visually stunning talk, Allan Jones shows how his team is mapping which genes are turned on in each tiny region, and how it all connects up. How the Mind Works,What's Next in Tech,Tales of Invention,brain,disease,science,technology  A map of the brain
text.829:
Charlie Todd causes bizarre, hilarious, and unexpected public scenes: Seventy synchronized dancers in storefront windows, "ghostbusters" running through the New York Public Library, and the annual no-pants subway ride. In his talk, he shows how his group, Improv Everywhere, uses these scenes to bring people together.
(Filmed at  TEDxBloomington.) The Creative Spark,Spectacular Performance,Art Unusual,The Rise of Collaboration,Master Storytellers,Not Business as Usual,Whipsmart Comedy,TEDx,comedy,community,culture,entertainment  The shared experience of absurdity
text.830: What controls aging? Biochemist Cynthia Kenyon has found a simple genetic mutation that can double the lifespan of a simple worm, C. elegans. The lessons from that discovery, and others, are pointing to how we might one day significantly extend youthful human life. Evolution's Genius,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,Women Reshaping the World,aging,biotech,genetics,medicine,science,technology  Experiments that hint of longer lives
text.831: Engineering student Péter Fankhauser demonstrates Rezero, a robot that balances on a ball. Designed and built by students, Rezero is the first ballbot made to move quickly and gracefully -- and even dance. (Could the Star Wars sphere droid be real? Watch this and judge.) Tales of Invention,creativity,design,engineering,robots,technology  Meet Rezero, the dancing ballbot
text.832:
iPad storyteller Joe Sabia introduces us to Lothar Meggendorfer, who created a bold technology for storytelling: the pop-up book. Sabia shows how new technology has always helped us tell our own stories, from the walls of caves to his own onstage iPad. 
 Art Unusual,Design That Matters,Media With Meaning,creativity,design,entertainment,storytelling,technology  The technology of storytelling
text.833:
Nature’s beauty can be easily missed -- but not through Louie Schwartzberg’s lens. His stunning time-lapse photography, accompanied by powerful words from Benedictine monk Brother David Steindl-Rast, serves as a meditation on being grateful for every day.
(Filmed at TEDxSF.) Art Unusual,TEDx,biodiversity,biology,compassion,culture,photography  Nature. Beauty. Gratitude.
text.834: When she was 19, Amy Purdy lost both her legs below the knee. And now ... she's a pro snowboarder (and a killer competitor on "Dancing with the Stars"!). In this powerful talk, she shows us how to draw inspiration from life's obstacles. What Makes Us Happy?,TEDx,entertainment,happiness,illness,personal growth,prosthetics  Living beyond limits
text.835:
Damon Horowitz teaches philosophy through the Prison University Project, bringing college-level classes to inmates of San Quentin State Prison. In this powerful short talk, he tells the story of an encounter with right and wrong that quickly gets personal.
 Master Storytellers,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,How We Learn,TED Conference,crime,culture,education,global issues,philosophy,prison  Philosophy in prison
text.836: Political prisoners aren't the only ones being tortured -- the vast majority of judicial torture happens in ordinary cases, even in 'functioning' legal systems. Social activist Karen Tse shows how we can, and should, stand up and end the use of routine torture. War and Peace,Women Reshaping the World,global issues,law,politics,prison,war  How to stop torture
text.837: Pop quiz: When does learning begin? Answer: Before we are born. Science writer Annie Murphy Paul talks through new research that shows how much we learn in the womb -- from the lilt of our native language to our soon-to-be-favorite foods. How the Mind Works,How We Learn,children,education,food,science,writing  What we learn before we're born
text.838:
Use dancers instead of powerpoint. That's science writer John Bohannon's "modest proposal." In this spellbinding choreographed talk he makes his case by example, aided by dancers from Black Label Movement.
(Filmed at TEDxBrussels.) The Creative Spark,Spectacular Performance,Art Unusual,Design That Matters,Media With Meaning,TEDx,biology,dance,entertainment,physics,presentation,science,technology  Dance vs. powerpoint, a modest proposal
text.839: Charles Limb performs cochlear implantation, a surgery that treats hearing loss and can restore the ability to hear speech. But as a musician too, Limb thinks about what the implants lack: They don't let you fully experience music yet. (There's a hair-raising example.) At TEDMED, Limb reviews the state of the art and the way forward. Tales of Invention,Medicine Without Borders,beauty,medical research,music,science,technology  Building the musical muscle
text.840: Cheryl Hayashi studies spider silk, one of nature's most high-performance materials. Each species of spider can make up to 7 very different kinds of silk. How do they do it? Hayashi explains at the DNA level -- then shows us how this super-strong, super-flexible material can inspire. Animals That Amaze,Inspired by Nature,MacArthur grant,TED Conference,biomechanics,biomimicry,science,technology  The magnificence of spider silk
text.841: Imagine having a surgery with no knives involved. At TEDMED, Yoav Medan shares a technique that uses MRI to find trouble spots and focused ultrasound to treat such issues as brain lesions, uterine fibroids and several kinds of cancerous growths. Medicine Without Borders,health care,medical research,medicine,science,technology  Ultrasound surgery -- healing without cuts
text.842: What is a mistake? By talking through examples with his improvisational Jazz quartet, Stefon Harris walks us to a profound truth: many actions are perceived as mistakes only because we don't react to them appropriately. The Creative Spark,The Rise of Collaboration,Live Music,culture,entertainment,jazz,music  There are no mistakes on the bandstand
text.843: Surgeons are taught from textbooks which conveniently color-code the types of tissues, but that's not what it looks like in real life -- until now. At TEDMED Quyen Nguyen demonstrates how a molecular marker can make tumors light up in neon green, showing surgeons exactly where to cut. Tales of Invention,Medicine Without Borders,Women Reshaping the World,cancer,medicine,science,technology  Color-coded surgery
text.844: Every day, we use materials from the earth without thinking, for free. But what if we had to pay for their true value: would it make us more careful about what we use and what we waste? Think of Pavan Sukhdev as nature's banker -- assessing the value of the Earth's assets. Eye-opening charts will make you think differently about the cost of air, water, trees ... A Greener Future?,business,economics,finance,global issues,green  Put a value on nature!
text.845: Homaro Cantu and Ben Roche come from Moto, a Chicago restaurant that plays with new ways to cook and eat food. But beyond the fun and flavor-tripping, there's a serious intent: Can we use new food technology for good? Art Unusual,Design That Matters,Food Matters,TED Conference,agriculture,business,creativity,culture,food  Cooking as alchemy
text.846:
When Ramona Pierson was 22, she was hit by a drunk driver and spent 18 months in a coma. In this talk, she tells the remarkable story of her recovery -- drawing on the collective skills and wisdom of a senior citizens' home.

(Filmed at TEDxDU.) Master Storytellers,Medicine Without Borders,TEDx,aging,culture,education,health care,medicine,self,storytelling  An unexpected place of healing
text.847: Every morning we wake up and regain consciousness -- that is a marvelous fact -- but what exactly is it that we regain? Neuroscientist Antonio Damasio uses this simple question to give us a glimpse into how our brains create our sense of self. How the Mind Works,TED Conference,brain,consciousness,neuroscience,science,self  The quest to understand consciousness
text.848: At TEDMED, Sheila Nirenberg shows a bold way to create sight in people with certain kinds of blindness: by hooking into the optic nerve and sending signals from a camera direct to the brain. Tales of Invention,Medicine Without Borders,Women Reshaping the World,medical research,medicine,science,sight,technology  A prosthetic eye to treat blindness
text.849: Every day, we make decisions that have good or bad consequences for our future selves. (Can I skip flossing just this one time?) Daniel Goldstein makes tools that help us imagine ourselves over time, so that we make smart choices for Future Us. How the Mind Works,What Makes Us Happy?,behavioral economics,business,culture,decision-making,economics,finance,self  The battle between your present and future self
text.850:
Alberto Cairo's clinics in Afghanistan used to close down during active fighting. Now, they stay open. In this powerful talk, Cairo tells the moving story of why -- and how he found humanity and dignity in the midst of war.
(Filmed at TEDxRC2.)
 Master Storytellers,Medicine Without Borders,TEDx,disability,global issues,poverty,prosthetics,storytelling,war,work  There are no scraps of men
text.851: For a full year, AJ Jacobs followed every piece of health advice he could -- from applying sunscreen by the shot glass to wearing a bicycle helmet while shopping. Onstage at TEDMED, he shares the surprising things he learned. Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,Medicine Without Borders,culture,entertainment,health,humor,self  How healthy living nearly killed me
text.852:
Within this generation, an extra 30 years have been added to our life expectancy -- and these years aren’t just a footnote or a pathology. In this talk, Jane Fonda asks how we can think about this new phase of our lives.

(Filmed at TEDxWomen.) What Makes Us Happy?,Might You Live a Great Deal Longer?,Medicine Without Borders,TEDx,aging,culture,health  Life's third act
text.853:
Paddy Ashdown claims that we are living in a moment in history where power is changing in ways it never has before. In a spellbinding talk he outlines the three major global shifts that he sees coming.
(Filmed at TEDxBrussels.) The Rise of Collaboration,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Europe,Foreign Policy,TEDx,global issues,politics,world cultures  The global power shift
text.854:
In 2011 three young women swept the top prizes of the first Google Science Fair. Lauren Hodge, Shree Bose and Naomi Shah describe their extraordinary projects -- and their route to a passion for science.

(Filmed at TEDxWomen.) Medicine Without Borders,Women Reshaping the World,TEDx,cancer,medicine,pollution,science,youth  Award-winning teenage science in action
text.855:
In politics, it seems counterintuitive to engage in dialogue with violent groups, with radicals and terrorists, and with the states that support them. But Jonas Gahr Støre, the foreign minister of Norway, makes a compelling case for open discussion, even when values diverge, in an attempt to build greater security for all.

(Filmed at TEDxRC2.) Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,War and Peace,TEDx,culture,politics  In defense of dialogue
text.856:
We have no ways to directly observe molecules and what they do -- Drew Berry wants to change that.  In this talk, he shows his scientifically accurate (and entertaining!) animations that help researchers see unseeable processes within our own cells.

(Filmed at TEDxSydney.) Evolution's Genius,TEDx,arts,biology,science,visualizations  Animations of unseeable biology
text.857:
Inspired by Aung San Suu Kyi’s call to action, “If you’re feeling helpless, help someone,” Morley composed this song. She sings it at TEDxWomen in her gorgeous, warm voice.

(Filmed at TEDxWomen.) Live Music,Women Reshaping the World,TEDx,activism,arts,music,poetry,women  "Women of Hope"
text.858: What aspects of religion should atheists (respectfully) adopt? Alain de Botton suggests a "religion for atheists" -- call it Atheism 2.0 -- that incorporates religious forms and traditions to satisfy our human need for connection, ritual and transcendence. Is There a God?,What Makes Us Happy?,atheism,culture,philosophy,religion  Atheism 2.0
text.859:
Cybercrime expert Mikko Hypponen talks us through three types of online attack on our privacy and data -- and only two are considered crimes. "Do we blindly trust any future government? Because any right we give away, we give away for good."
(Filmed at TEDxBrussels.)
 What's Next in Tech,Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Internet,crime,data,politics,technology  Three types of online attack
text.860: What does a bill like PIPA/SOPA mean to our shareable world? At the TED offices, Clay Shirky delivers a proper manifesto -- a call to defend our freedom to create, discuss, link and share, rather than passively consume. Master Storytellers,Media With Meaning,business,creativity,media,politics,technology  Why SOPA is a bad idea
text.861: We all want customized experiences and products -- but when faced with 700 options, consumers freeze up. With fascinating new research, Sheena Iyengar demonstrates how businesses (and others) can improve the experience of choosing. Not Business as Usual,business,choice,culture,decision-making,marketing  How to make choosing easier
text.862: Algae plus salt water equals … fuel? At TEDxNASA@SiliconValley, Bilal Bomani reveals a self-sustaining ecosystem that produces biofuels -- without wasting arable land or fresh water. A Greener Future?,Tales of Invention,TEDx,science,sustainability,technology  Plant fuels that could power a jet
text.863: 2012 may be the year of 3D printing, when this three-decade-old technology finally becomes accessible and even commonplace. Lisa Harouni gives a useful introduction to this fascinating way of making things -- including intricate objects once impossible to create. Design That Matters,business,design,technology  A primer on 3D printing
text.864:
Every doctor makes mistakes. But, says physician Brian Goldman, medicine's culture of denial (and shame) keeps doctors from ever talking about those mistakes, or using them to learn and improve. Telling stories from his own long practice, he calls on doctors to start talking about being wrong.

(Filmed at TEDxToronto.) Medicine Without Borders,TEDx,communication,culture,medicine,public health  Doctors make mistakes. Can we talk about that?
text.865:
Imagine playing a video game controlled by your mind. Now imagine that game also teaches you about your own patterns of stress, relaxation and focus. Ariel Garten shows how looking at our own brain activity gives new meaning to the ancient dictum "know thyself."
(Filmed at TEDxToronto.) How the Mind Works,What's Next in Tech,Art Unusual,Women Reshaping the World,TEDx,arts,neuroscience,psychology,science,technology  Know thyself, with a brain scanner
text.866: Women aren’t micro--so why do they only get micro-loans? Reporter Gayle Tzemach Lemmon argues that women running all types of firms-- from home businesses to major factories-- are the overlooked key to economic development. Media With Meaning,Women Reshaping the World,TEDx,entrepreneur,global issues,poverty,women,women in business  Women entrepreneurs, example not exception
text.867: We make millions of online purchases daily, but who (or what) actually puts our items into packages? In this talk, Mick Mountz weaves a fascinating, surprisingly robot-filled tale of what happens inside a warehouse. Not Business as Usual,TEDx,business,consumerism,robots,shopping,technology  What happens inside those massive warehouses?
text.868:
Peter van Uhm is the Netherlands’ chief of defense, but that does not mean he is pro-war. In this talk, he explains how his career is one shaped by a love of peace, not a desire for bloodshed -- and why we need armies if we want peace.
(Filmed at TEDxAmsterdam.) War and Peace,TEDx,global issues,military,peace,war  Why I chose a gun
text.869: Surgery, chemotherapy and radiation are the best-known methods for treating cancer. At TEDMED, Bill Doyle presents a new approach, called Tumor Treating Fields, which uses electric fields to interrupt cancer cell division. Still in its infancy -- and approved for only certain types of cancer -- the treatment comes with one big benefit: quality of life. Medicine Without Borders,cancer,medical research,technology  Treating cancer with electric fields
text.870:
We believe that we should work to be happy, but could that be backwards? In this fast-moving and entertaining talk, psychologist Shawn Achor argues that actually happiness inspires productivity.
(Filmed at TEDxBloomington.) Not Business as Usual,What Makes Us Happy?,TEDx,business,happiness,psychology,science  The happy secret to better work
text.871: What if you're in surgery and the power goes out? No lights, no oxygen -- and your anesthesia stops flowing. It happens constantly in hospitals throughout the world, turning routine procedures into tragedies. Erica Frenkel demos one solution: the universal anesthesia machine. Medicine Without Borders,Surgery,TEDx,design,global issues,health care,poverty,technology  The universal anesthesia machine
text.872: From deep in the TED archive, Danny Hillis outlines an intriguing theory of how and why technological change seems to be accelerating, by linking it to the very evolution of life itself.  The presentation techniques he uses may look dated, but the ideas are as relevant as ever. Evolution's Genius,What's Next in Tech,TED Conference,future,science,technology  Back to the future (of 1994)
text.873: How do you remember where you parked your car? How do you know if you're moving in the right direction? Neuroscientist Neil Burgess studies the neural mechanisms that map the space around us, and how they link to memory and imagination. How the Mind Works,brain,cognitive science,exploration,neuroscience,science  How your brain tells you where you are
text.874:
Pepper spray and tasers are in increasing use by both police and military, and more exotic non-lethal weapons such as heat rays are in the works. In this talk, ethicist Stephen Coleman explores the unexpected consequences of their introduction and asks some challenging questions.

(Filmed at TEDxCanberra.) Bold Predictions, Stern Warnings,Technology, History and Destiny,War and Peace,TEDx,corruption,culture,global issues,military,morality,technology,war  The moral dangers of non-lethal weapons
text.875: Sheikha Al Mayassa, a patron of artists, storytellers and filmmakers in Qatar, talks about how art and culture create a country's identity -- and allow every country to share its unique identity with the wider world.
